          Line data    Source code
       1             : /*-------------------------------------------------------------------------
       2             :  *
       3             :  * xlog.c
       4             :  *      PostgreSQL write-ahead log manager
       5             :  *
       6             :  * The Write-Ahead Log (WAL) functionality is split into several source
       7             :  * files, in addition to this one:
       8             :  *
       9             :  * xloginsert.c - Functions for constructing WAL records
      10             :  * xlogrecovery.c - WAL recovery and standby code
      11             :  * xlogreader.c - Facility for reading WAL files and parsing WAL records
      12             :  * xlogutils.c - Helper functions for WAL redo routines
      13             :  *
      14             :  * This file contains functions for coordinating database startup and
      15             :  * checkpointing, and managing the write-ahead log buffers when the
      16             :  * system is running.
      17             :  *
      18             :  * StartupXLOG() is the main entry point of the startup process.  It
      19             :  * coordinates database startup, performing WAL recovery, and the
      20             :  * transition from WAL recovery into normal operations.
      21             :  *
      22             :  * XLogInsertRecord() inserts a WAL record into the WAL buffers.  Most
      23             :  * callers should not call this directly, but use the functions in
      24             :  * xloginsert.c to construct the WAL record.  XLogFlush() can be used
      25             :  * to force the WAL to disk.
      26             :  *
      27             :  * In addition to those, there are many other functions for interrogating
      28             :  * the current system state, and for starting/stopping backups.
      29             :  *
      30             :  *
      31             :  * Portions Copyright (c) 1996-2024, PostgreSQL Global Development Group
      32             :  * Portions Copyright (c) 1994, Regents of the University of California
      33             :  *
      34             :  * src/backend/access/transam/xlog.c
      35             :  *
      36             :  *-------------------------------------------------------------------------
      37             :  */
      38             : 
      39             : #include "postgres.h"
      40             : 
      41             : #include <ctype.h>
      42             : #include <math.h>
      43             : #include <time.h>
      44             : #include <fcntl.h>
      45             : #include <sys/stat.h>
      46             : #include <sys/time.h>
      47             : #include <unistd.h>

     100             : #include "storage/sync.h"

     110             : #include "utils/varlena.h"
     111             : 
     112             : extern uint32 bootstrap_data_checksum_version;
     113             : 
     114             : /* timeline ID to be used when bootstrapping */
     115             : #define BootstrapTimeLineID     1
     116             : 
     117             : /* User-settable parameters */
     118             : int         max_wal_size_mb = 1024; /* 1 GB */
     119             : int         min_wal_size_mb = 80;   /* 80 MB */
     120             : int         wal_keep_size_mb = 0;
     121             : int         XLOGbuffers = -1;
     122             : int         XLogArchiveTimeout = 0;
     123             : int         XLogArchiveMode = ARCHIVE_MODE_OFF;
     124             : char       *XLogArchiveCommand = NULL;
     125             : bool        EnableHotStandby = false;
     126             : bool        fullPageWrites = true;
     127             : bool        wal_log_hints = false;
     128             : int         wal_compression = WAL_COMPRESSION_NONE;
     129             : char       *wal_consistency_checking_string = NULL;
     130             : bool       *wal_consistency_checking = NULL;
     131             : bool        wal_init_zero = true;
     132             : bool        wal_recycle = true;
     133             : bool        log_checkpoints = true;
     134             : int         wal_sync_method = DEFAULT_WAL_SYNC_METHOD;
     135             : int         wal_level = WAL_LEVEL_REPLICA;
     136             : int         CommitDelay = 0;    /* precommit delay in microseconds */
     137             : int         CommitSiblings = 5; /* # concurrent xacts needed to sleep */
     138             : int         wal_retrieve_retry_interval = 5000;
     139             : int         max_slot_wal_keep_size_mb = -1;
     140             : int         wal_decode_buffer_size = 512 * 1024;
     141             : bool        track_wal_io_timing = false;
     142             : 
     143             : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG
     144             : bool        XLOG_DEBUG = false;
     145             : #endif
     146             : 
     147             : int         wal_segment_size = DEFAULT_XLOG_SEG_SIZE;
     148             : 
     149             : /*
     150             :  * Number of WAL insertion locks to use. A higher value allows more insertions
     151             :  * to happen concurrently, but adds some CPU overhead to flushing the WAL,
     152             :  * which needs to iterate all the locks.
     153             :  */
     154             : #define NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS  8
     155             : 
     156             : /*
     157             :  * Max distance from last checkpoint, before triggering a new xlog-based
     158             :  * checkpoint.
     159             :  */
     160             : int         CheckPointSegments;
     161             : 
     162             : /* Estimated distance between checkpoints, in bytes */
     163             : static double CheckPointDistanceEstimate = 0;
     164             : static double PrevCheckPointDistance = 0;
     165             : 
     166             : /*
     167             :  * Track whether there were any deferred checks for custom resource managers
     168             :  * specified in wal_consistency_checking.
     169             :  */
     170             : static bool check_wal_consistency_checking_deferred = false;
     171             : 
     172             : /*
     173             :  * GUC support
     174             :  */
     175             : const struct config_enum_entry wal_sync_method_options[] = {
     176             :     {"fsync", WAL_SYNC_METHOD_FSYNC, false},
     177             : #ifdef HAVE_FSYNC_WRITETHROUGH
     178             :     {"fsync_writethrough", WAL_SYNC_METHOD_FSYNC_WRITETHROUGH, false},
     179             : #endif
     180             :     {"fdatasync", WAL_SYNC_METHOD_FDATASYNC, false},
     181             : #ifdef O_SYNC
     182             :     {"open_sync", WAL_SYNC_METHOD_OPEN, false},
     183             : #endif
     184             : #ifdef O_DSYNC
     185             :     {"open_datasync", WAL_SYNC_METHOD_OPEN_DSYNC, false},
     186             : #endif
     187             :     {NULL, 0, false}
     188             : };
     189             : 
     190             : 
     191             : /*
     192             :  * Although only "on", "off", and "always" are documented,
     193             :  * we accept all the likely variants of "on" and "off".
     194             :  */
     195             : const struct config_enum_entry archive_mode_options[] = {
     196             :     {"always", ARCHIVE_MODE_ALWAYS, false},
     197             :     {"on", ARCHIVE_MODE_ON, false},
     198             :     {"off", ARCHIVE_MODE_OFF, false},
     199             :     {"true", ARCHIVE_MODE_ON, true},
     200             :     {"false", ARCHIVE_MODE_OFF, true},
     201             :     {"yes", ARCHIVE_MODE_ON, true},
     202             :     {"no", ARCHIVE_MODE_OFF, true},
     203             :     {"1", ARCHIVE_MODE_ON, true},
     204             :     {"0", ARCHIVE_MODE_OFF, true},
     205             :     {NULL, 0, false}
     206             : };
     207             : 
     208             : /*
     209             :  * Statistics for current checkpoint are collected in this global struct.
     210             :  * Because only the checkpointer or a stand-alone backend can perform
     211             :  * checkpoints, this will be unused in normal backends.
     212             :  */
     213             : CheckpointStatsData CheckpointStats;
     214             : 
     215             : /*
     216             :  * During recovery, lastFullPageWrites keeps track of full_page_writes that
     217             :  * the replayed WAL records indicate. It's initialized with full_page_writes
     218             :  * that the recovery starting checkpoint record indicates, and then updated
     219             :  * each time XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record is replayed.
     220             :  */
     221             : static bool lastFullPageWrites;
     222             : 
     223             : /*
     224             :  * Local copy of the state tracked by SharedRecoveryState in shared memory,
     225             :  * It is false if SharedRecoveryState is RECOVERY_STATE_DONE.  True actually
     226             :  * means "not known, need to check the shared state".
     227             :  */
     228             : static bool LocalRecoveryInProgress = true;
     229             : 
     230             : /*
     231             :  * Local state for XLogInsertAllowed():
     232             :  *      1: unconditionally allowed to insert XLOG
     233             :  *      0: unconditionally not allowed to insert XLOG
     234             :  *      -1: must check RecoveryInProgress(); disallow until it is false
     235             :  * Most processes start with -1 and transition to 1 after seeing that recovery
     236             :  * is not in progress.  But we can also force the value for special cases.
     237             :  * The coding in XLogInsertAllowed() depends on the first two of these states
     238             :  * being numerically the same as bool true and false.
     239             :  */
     240             : static int  LocalXLogInsertAllowed = -1;
     241             : 
     242             : /*
     243             :  * ProcLastRecPtr points to the start of the last XLOG record inserted by the
     244             :  * current backend.  It is updated for all inserts.  XactLastRecEnd points to
     245             :  * end+1 of the last record, and is reset when we end a top-level transaction,
     246             :  * or start a new one; so it can be used to tell if the current transaction has
     247             :  * created any XLOG records.
     248             :  *
     249             :  * While in parallel mode, this may not be fully up to date.  When committing,
     250             :  * a transaction can assume this covers all xlog records written either by the
     251             :  * user backend or by any parallel worker which was present at any point during
     252             :  * the transaction.  But when aborting, or when still in parallel mode, other
     253             :  * parallel backends may have written WAL records at later LSNs than the value
     254             :  * stored here.  The parallel leader advances its own copy, when necessary,
     255             :  * in WaitForParallelWorkersToFinish.
     256             :  */
     257             : XLogRecPtr  ProcLastRecPtr = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     258             : XLogRecPtr  XactLastRecEnd = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     259             : XLogRecPtr  XactLastCommitEnd = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     260             : 
     261             : /*
     262             :  * RedoRecPtr is this backend's local copy of the REDO record pointer
     263             :  * (which is almost but not quite the same as a pointer to the most recent
     264             :  * CHECKPOINT record).  We update this from the shared-memory copy,
     265             :  * XLogCtl->Insert.RedoRecPtr, whenever we can safely do so (ie, when we
     266             :  * hold an insertion lock).  See XLogInsertRecord for details.  We are also
     267             :  * allowed to update from XLogCtl->RedoRecPtr if we hold the info_lck;
     268             :  * see GetRedoRecPtr.
     269             :  *
     270             :  * NB: Code that uses this variable must be prepared not only for the
     271             :  * possibility that it may be arbitrarily out of date, but also for the
     272             :  * possibility that it might be set to InvalidXLogRecPtr. We used to
     273             :  * initialize it as a side effect of the first call to RecoveryInProgress(),
     274             :  * which meant that most code that might use it could assume that it had a
     275             :  * real if perhaps stale value. That's no longer the case.
     276             :  */
     277             : static XLogRecPtr RedoRecPtr;
     278             : 
     279             : /*
     280             :  * doPageWrites is this backend's local copy of (fullPageWrites ||
     281             :  * runningBackups > 0).  It is used together with RedoRecPtr to decide whether
     282             :  * a full-page image of a page need to be taken.
     283             :  *
     284             :  * NB: Initially this is false, and there's no guarantee that it will be
     285             :  * initialized to any other value before it is first used. Any code that
     286             :  * makes use of it must recheck the value after obtaining a WALInsertLock,
     287             :  * and respond appropriately if it turns out that the previous value wasn't
     288             :  * accurate.
     289             :  */
     290             : static bool doPageWrites;
     291             : 
     292             : /*----------
     293             :  * Shared-memory data structures for XLOG control
     294             :  *
     295             :  * LogwrtRqst indicates a byte position that we need to write and/or fsync
     296             :  * the log up to (all records before that point must be written or fsynced).
     297             :  * LogwrtResult indicates the byte positions we have already written/fsynced.
     298             :  * These structs are identical but are declared separately to indicate their
     299             :  * slightly different functions.
     300             :  *
     301             :  * To read XLogCtl->LogwrtResult, you must hold either info_lck or
     302             :  * WALWriteLock.  To update it, you need to hold both locks.  The point of
     303             :  * this arrangement is that the value can be examined by code that already
     304             :  * holds WALWriteLock without needing to grab info_lck as well.  In addition
     305             :  * to the shared variable, each backend has a private copy of LogwrtResult,
     306             :  * which is updated when convenient.
     307             :  *
     308             :  * The request bookkeeping is simpler: there is a shared XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst
     309             :  * (protected by info_lck), but we don't need to cache any copies of it.
     310             :  *
     311             :  * info_lck is only held long enough to read/update the protected variables,
     312             :  * so it's a plain spinlock.  The other locks are held longer (potentially
     313             :  * over I/O operations), so we use LWLocks for them.  These locks are:
     314             :  *
     315             :  * WALBufMappingLock: must be held to replace a page in the WAL buffer cache.
     316             :  * It is only held while initializing and changing the mapping.  If the
     317             :  * contents of the buffer being replaced haven't been written yet, the mapping
     318             :  * lock is released while the write is done, and reacquired afterwards.
     319             :  *
     320             :  * WALWriteLock: must be held to write WAL buffers to disk (XLogWrite or
     321             :  * XLogFlush).
     322             :  *
     323             :  * ControlFileLock: must be held to read/update control file or create
     324             :  * new log file.
     325             :  *
     326             :  *----------
     327             :  */
     328             : 
     329             : typedef struct XLogwrtRqst
     330             : {
     331             :     XLogRecPtr  Write;          /* last byte + 1 to write out */
     332             :     XLogRecPtr  Flush;          /* last byte + 1 to flush */
     333             : } XLogwrtRqst;
     334             : 
     335             : typedef struct XLogwrtResult
     336             : {
     337             :     XLogRecPtr  Write;          /* last byte + 1 written out */
     338             :     XLogRecPtr  Flush;          /* last byte + 1 flushed */
     339             : } XLogwrtResult;
     340             : 
     341             : /*
     342             :  * Inserting to WAL is protected by a small fixed number of WAL insertion
     343             :  * locks. To insert to the WAL, you must hold one of the locks - it doesn't
     344             :  * matter which one. To lock out other concurrent insertions, you must hold
     345             :  * of them. Each WAL insertion lock consists of a lightweight lock, plus an
     346             :  * indicator of how far the insertion has progressed (insertingAt).
     347             :  *
     348             :  * The insertingAt values are read when a process wants to flush WAL from
     349             :  * the in-memory buffers to disk, to check that all the insertions to the
     350             :  * region the process is about to write out have finished. You could simply
     351             :  * wait for all currently in-progress insertions to finish, but the
     352             :  * insertingAt indicator allows you to ignore insertions to later in the WAL,
     353             :  * so that you only wait for the insertions that are modifying the buffers
     354             :  * you're about to write out.
     355             :  *
     356             :  * This isn't just an optimization. If all the WAL buffers are dirty, an
     357             :  * inserter that's holding a WAL insert lock might need to evict an old WAL
     358             :  * buffer, which requires flushing the WAL. If it's possible for an inserter
     359             :  * to block on another inserter unnecessarily, deadlock can arise when two
     360             :  * inserters holding a WAL insert lock wait for each other to finish their
     361             :  * insertion.
     362             :  *
     363             :  * Small WAL records that don't cross a page boundary never update the value,
     364             :  * the WAL record is just copied to the page and the lock is released. But
     365             :  * to avoid the deadlock-scenario explained above, the indicator is always
     366             :  * updated before sleeping while holding an insertion lock.
     367             :  *
     368             :  * lastImportantAt contains the LSN of the last important WAL record inserted
     369             :  * using a given lock. This value is used to detect if there has been
     370             :  * important WAL activity since the last time some action, like a checkpoint,
     371             :  * was performed - allowing to not repeat the action if not. The LSN is
     372             :  * updated for all insertions, unless the XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT flag was
     373             :  * set. lastImportantAt is never cleared, only overwritten by the LSN of newer
     374             :  * records.  Tracking the WAL activity directly in WALInsertLock has the
     375             :  * advantage of not needing any additional locks to update the value.
     376             :  */
     377             : typedef struct
     378             : {
     379             :     LWLock      lock;
     380             :     pg_atomic_uint64 insertingAt;
     381             :     XLogRecPtr  lastImportantAt;
     382             : } WALInsertLock;
     383             : 
     384             : /*
     385             :  * All the WAL insertion locks are allocated as an array in shared memory. We
     386             :  * force the array stride to be a power of 2, which saves a few cycles in
     387             :  * indexing, but more importantly also ensures that individual slots don't
     388             :  * cross cache line boundaries. (Of course, we have to also ensure that the
     389             :  * array start address is suitably aligned.)
     390             :  */
     391             : typedef union WALInsertLockPadded
     392             : {
     393             :     WALInsertLock l;
     394             :     char        pad[PG_CACHE_LINE_SIZE];
     395             : } WALInsertLockPadded;
     396             : 
     397             : /*
     398             :  * Session status of running backup, used for sanity checks in SQL-callable
     399             :  * functions to start and stop backups.
     400             :  */
     401             : static SessionBackupState sessionBackupState = SESSION_BACKUP_NONE;
     402             : 
     403             : /*
     404             :  * Shared state data for WAL insertion.
     405             :  */
     406             : typedef struct XLogCtlInsert
     407             : {
     408             :     slock_t     insertpos_lck;  /* protects CurrBytePos and PrevBytePos */
     409             : 
     410             :     /*
     411             :      * CurrBytePos is the end of reserved WAL. The next record will be
     412             :      * inserted at that position. PrevBytePos is the start position of the
     413             :      * previously inserted (or rather, reserved) record - it is copied to the
     414             :      * prev-link of the next record. These are stored as "usable byte
     415             :      * positions" rather than XLogRecPtrs (see XLogBytePosToRecPtr()).
     416             :      */
     417             :     uint64      CurrBytePos;
     418             :     uint64      PrevBytePos;
     419             : 
     420             :     /*
     421             :      * Make sure the above heavily-contended spinlock and byte positions are
     422             :      * on their own cache line. In particular, the RedoRecPtr and full page
     423             :      * write variables below should be on a different cache line. They are
     424             :      * read on every WAL insertion, but updated rarely, and we don't want
     425             :      * those reads to steal the cache line containing Curr/PrevBytePos.
     426             :      */
     427             :     char        pad[PG_CACHE_LINE_SIZE];
     428             : 
     429             :     /*
     430             :      * fullPageWrites is the authoritative value used by all backends to
     431             :      * determine whether to write full-page image to WAL. This shared value,
     432             :      * instead of the process-local fullPageWrites, is required because, when
     433             :      * full_page_writes is changed by SIGHUP, we must WAL-log it before it
     434             :      * actually affects WAL-logging by backends.  Checkpointer sets at startup
     435             :      * or after SIGHUP.
     436             :      *
     437             :      * To read these fields, you must hold an insertion lock. To modify them,
     438             :      * you must hold ALL the locks.
     439             :      */
     440             :     XLogRecPtr  RedoRecPtr;     /* current redo point for insertions */
     441             :     bool        fullPageWrites;
     442             : 
     443             :     /*
     444             :      * runningBackups is a counter indicating the number of backups currently
     445             :      * in progress. lastBackupStart is the latest checkpoint redo location
     446             :      * used as a starting point for an online backup.
     447             :      */
     448             :     int         runningBackups;
     449             :     XLogRecPtr  lastBackupStart;
     450             : 
     451             :     /*
     452             :      * WAL insertion locks.
     453             :      */
     454             :     WALInsertLockPadded *WALInsertLocks;
     455             : } XLogCtlInsert;
     456             : 
     457             : /*
     458             :  * Total shared-memory state for XLOG.
     459             :  */
     460             : typedef struct XLogCtlData
     461             : {
     462             :     XLogCtlInsert Insert;
     463             : 
     464             :     /* Protected by info_lck: */
     465             :     XLogwrtRqst LogwrtRqst;
     466             :     XLogRecPtr  RedoRecPtr;     /* a recent copy of Insert->RedoRecPtr */
     467             :     FullTransactionId ckptFullXid;  /* nextXid of latest checkpoint */
     468             :     XLogRecPtr  asyncXactLSN;   /* LSN of newest async commit/abort */
     469             :     XLogRecPtr  replicationSlotMinLSN;  /* oldest LSN needed by any slot */
     470             : 
     471             :     XLogSegNo   lastRemovedSegNo;   /* latest removed/recycled XLOG segment */
     472             : 
     473             :     /* Fake LSN counter, for unlogged relations. Protected by ulsn_lck. */
     474             :     XLogRecPtr  unloggedLSN;
     475             :     slock_t     ulsn_lck;
     476             : 
     477             :     /* Time and LSN of last xlog segment switch. Protected by WALWriteLock. */
     478             :     pg_time_t   lastSegSwitchTime;
     479             :     XLogRecPtr  lastSegSwitchLSN;
     480             : 
     481             :     /*
     482             :      * Protected by info_lck and WALWriteLock (you must hold either lock to
     483             :      * read it, but both to update)
     484             :      */
     485             :     XLogwrtResult LogwrtResult;
     486             : 
     487             :     /*
     488             :      * Latest initialized page in the cache (last byte position + 1).
     489             :      *
     490             :      * To change the identity of a buffer (and InitializedUpTo), you need to
     491             :      * hold WALBufMappingLock.  To change the identity of a buffer that's
     492             :      * still dirty, the old page needs to be written out first, and for that
     493             :      * you need WALWriteLock, and you need to ensure that there are no
     494             :      * in-progress insertions to the page by calling
     495             :      * WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish().
     496             :      */
     497             :     XLogRecPtr  InitializedUpTo;
     498             : 
     499             :     /*
     500             :      * These values do not change after startup, although the pointed-to pages
     501             :      * and xlblocks values certainly do.  xlblocks values are protected by
     502             :      * WALBufMappingLock.
     503             :      */
     504             :     char       *pages;          /* buffers for unwritten XLOG pages */
     505             :     pg_atomic_uint64 *xlblocks; /* 1st byte ptr-s + XLOG_BLCKSZ */
     506             :     int         XLogCacheBlck;  /* highest allocated xlog buffer index */
     507             : 
     508             :     /*
     509             :      * InsertTimeLineID is the timeline into which new WAL is being inserted
     510             :      * and flushed. It is zero during recovery, and does not change once set.
     511             :      *
     512             :      * If we create a new timeline when the system was started up,
     513             :      * PrevTimeLineID is the old timeline's ID that we forked off from.
     514             :      * Otherwise it's equal to InsertTimeLineID.
     515             :      */
     516             :     TimeLineID  InsertTimeLineID;
     517             :     TimeLineID  PrevTimeLineID;
     518             : 
     519             :     /*
     520             :      * SharedRecoveryState indicates if we're still in crash or archive
     521             :      * recovery.  Protected by info_lck.
     522             :      */
     523             :     RecoveryState SharedRecoveryState;
     524             : 
     525             :     /*
     526             :      * InstallXLogFileSegmentActive indicates whether the checkpointer should
     527             :      * arrange for future segments by recycling and/or PreallocXlogFiles().
     528             :      * Protected by ControlFileLock.  Only the startup process changes it.  If
     529             :      * true, anyone can use InstallXLogFileSegment().  If false, the startup
     530             :      * process owns the exclusive right to install segments, by reading from
     531             :      * the archive and possibly replacing existing files.
     532             :      */
     533             :     bool        InstallXLogFileSegmentActive;
     534             : 
     535             :     /*
     536             :      * WalWriterSleeping indicates whether the WAL writer is currently in
     537             :      * low-power mode (and hence should be nudged if an async commit occurs).
     538             :      * Protected by info_lck.
     539             :      */
     540             :     bool        WalWriterSleeping;
     541             : 
     542             :     /*
     543             :      * During recovery, we keep a copy of the latest checkpoint record here.
     544             :      * lastCheckPointRecPtr points to start of checkpoint record and
     545             :      * lastCheckPointEndPtr points to end+1 of checkpoint record.  Used by the
     546             :      * checkpointer when it wants to create a restartpoint.
     547             :      *
     548             :      * Protected by info_lck.
     549             :      */
     550             :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointRecPtr;
     551             :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointEndPtr;
     552             :     CheckPoint  lastCheckPoint;
     553             : 
     554             :     /*
     555             :      * lastFpwDisableRecPtr points to the start of the last replayed
     556             :      * XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record that instructs full_page_writes is disabled.
     557             :      */
     558             :     XLogRecPtr  lastFpwDisableRecPtr;
     559             : 
     560             :     slock_t     info_lck;       /* locks shared variables shown above */
     561             : } XLogCtlData;
     562             : 
     563             : /*
     564             :  * Classification of XLogRecordInsert operations.
     565             :  */
     566             : typedef enum
     567             : {
     568             :     WALINSERT_NORMAL,
     569             :     WALINSERT_SPECIAL_SWITCH,
     570             :     WALINSERT_SPECIAL_CHECKPOINT
     571             : } WalInsertClass;
     572             : 
     573             : static XLogCtlData *XLogCtl = NULL;
     574             : 
     575             : /* a private copy of XLogCtl->Insert.WALInsertLocks, for convenience */
     576             : static WALInsertLockPadded *WALInsertLocks = NULL;
     577             : 
     578             : /*
     579             :  * We maintain an image of pg_control in shared memory.
     580             :  */
     581             : static ControlFileData *ControlFile = NULL;
     582             : 
     583             : /*
     584             :  * Calculate the amount of space left on the page after 'endptr'. Beware
     585             :  * multiple evaluation!
     586             :  */
     587             : #define INSERT_FREESPACE(endptr)    \
     588             :     (((endptr) % XLOG_BLCKSZ == 0) ? 0 : (XLOG_BLCKSZ - (endptr) % XLOG_BLCKSZ))
     589             : 
     590             : /* Macro to advance to next buffer index. */
     591             : #define NextBufIdx(idx)     \
     592             :         (((idx) == XLogCtl->XLogCacheBlck) ? 0 : ((idx) + 1))
     593             : 
     594             : /*
     595             :  * XLogRecPtrToBufIdx returns the index of the WAL buffer that holds, or
     596             :  * would hold if it was in cache, the page containing 'recptr'.
     597             :  */
     598             : #define XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(recptr)  \
     599             :     (((recptr) / XLOG_BLCKSZ) % (XLogCtl->XLogCacheBlck + 1))

     702             : static char *GetXLogBuffer(XLogRecPtr ptr, TimeLineID tli);

     704             : static XLogRecPtr XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(uint64 bytepos);
     705             : static uint64 XLogRecPtrToBytePos(XLogRecPtr ptr);
     706             : 
     707             : static void WALInsertLockAcquire(void);
     708             : static void WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive(void);
     709             : static void WALInsertLockRelease(void);
     710             : static void WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(XLogRecPtr insertingAt);
     711             : 
     712             : /*
     713             :  * Insert an XLOG record represented by an already-constructed chain of data
     714             :  * chunks.  This is a low-level routine; to construct the WAL record header
     715             :  * and data, use the higher-level routines in xloginsert.c.
     716             :  *
     717             :  * If 'fpw_lsn' is valid, it is the oldest LSN among the pages that this
     718             :  * WAL record applies to, that were not included in the record as full page
     719             :  * images.  If fpw_lsn <= RedoRecPtr, the function does not perform the
     720             :  * insertion and returns InvalidXLogRecPtr.  The caller can then recalculate
     721             :  * which pages need a full-page image, and retry.  If fpw_lsn is invalid, the
     722             :  * record is always inserted.
     723             :  *
     724             :  * 'flags' gives more in-depth control on the record being inserted. See
     725             :  * XLogSetRecordFlags() for details.
     726             :  *
     727             :  * 'topxid_included' tells whether the top-transaction id is logged along with
     728             :  * current subtransaction. See XLogRecordAssemble().
     729             :  *
     730             :  * The first XLogRecData in the chain must be for the record header, and its
     731             :  * data must be MAXALIGNed.  XLogInsertRecord fills in the xl_prev and
     732             :  * xl_crc fields in the header, the rest of the header must already be filled
     733             :  * by the caller.
     734             :  *
     735             :  * Returns XLOG pointer to end of record (beginning of next record).
     736             :  * This can be used as LSN for data pages affected by the logged action.
     737             :  * (LSN is the XLOG point up to which the XLOG must be flushed to disk
     738             :  * before the data page can be written out.  This implements the basic
     739             :  * WAL rule "write the log before the data".)
     740             :  */
     741             : XLogRecPtr
     742    24796030 : XLogInsertRecord(XLogRecData *rdata,
     743             :                  XLogRecPtr fpw_lsn,
     744             :                  uint8 flags,
     745             :                  int num_fpi,
     746             :                  bool topxid_included)
     747             : {
     748    24796030 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
     749             :     pg_crc32c   rdata_crc;
     750             :     bool        inserted;
     751    24796030 :     XLogRecord *rechdr = (XLogRecord *) rdata->data;
     752    24796030 :     uint8       info = rechdr->xl_info & ~XLR_INFO_MASK;
     753    24796030 :     WalInsertClass class = WALINSERT_NORMAL;
     754             :     XLogRecPtr  StartPos;
     755             :     XLogRecPtr  EndPos;
     756    24796030 :     bool        prevDoPageWrites = doPageWrites;
     757             :     TimeLineID  insertTLI;
     758             : 
     759             :     /* Does this record type require special handling? */
     760    24796030 :     if (unlikely(rechdr->xl_rmid == RM_XLOG_ID))
     761             :     {
     762      340580 :         if (info == XLOG_SWITCH)
     763         624 :             class = WALINSERT_SPECIAL_SWITCH;
     764      339956 :         else if (info == XLOG_CHECKPOINT_REDO)
     765         592 :             class = WALINSERT_SPECIAL_CHECKPOINT;
     766             :     }
     767             : 
     768             :     /* we assume that all of the record header is in the first chunk */
     769    24796030 :     Assert(rdata->len >= SizeOfXLogRecord);
     770             : 
     771             :     /* cross-check on whether we should be here or not */
     772    24796030 :     if (!XLogInsertAllowed())
     773           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cannot make new WAL entries during recovery");
     774             : 
     775             :     /*
     776             :      * Given that we're not in recovery, InsertTimeLineID is set and can't
     777             :      * change, so we can read it without a lock.
     778             :      */
     779    24796030 :     insertTLI = XLogCtl->InsertTimeLineID;
     780             : 
     781             :     /*----------
     782             :      *
     783             :      * We have now done all the preparatory work we can without holding a
     784             :      * lock or modifying shared state. From here on, inserting the new WAL
     785             :      * record to the shared WAL buffer cache is a two-step process:
     786             :      *
     787             :      * 1. Reserve the right amount of space from the WAL. The current head of
     788             :      *    reserved space is kept in Insert->CurrBytePos, and is protected by
     789             :      *    insertpos_lck.
     790             :      *
     791             :      * 2. Copy the record to the reserved WAL space. This involves finding the
     792             :      *    correct WAL buffer containing the reserved space, and copying the
     793             :      *    record in place. This can be done concurrently in multiple processes.
     794             :      *
     795             :      * To keep track of which insertions are still in-progress, each concurrent
     796             :      * inserter acquires an insertion lock. In addition to just indicating that
     797             :      * an insertion is in progress, the lock tells others how far the inserter
     798             :      * has progressed. There is a small fixed number of insertion locks,
     799             :      * determined by NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS. When an inserter crosses a page
     800             :      * boundary, it updates the value stored in the lock to the how far it has
     801             :      * inserted, to allow the previous buffer to be flushed.
     802             :      *
     803             :      * Holding onto an insertion lock also protects RedoRecPtr and
     804             :      * fullPageWrites from changing until the insertion is finished.
     805             :      *
     806             :      * Step 2 can usually be done completely in parallel. If the required WAL
     807             :      * page is not initialized yet, you have to grab WALBufMappingLock to
     808             :      * initialize it, but the WAL writer tries to do that ahead of insertions
     809             :      * to avoid that from happening in the critical path.
     810             :      *
     811             :      *----------
     812             :      */
     813    24796030 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
     814             : 
     815    24796030 :     if (likely(class == WALINSERT_NORMAL))
     816             :     {
     817    24794814 :         WALInsertLockAcquire();
     818             : 
     819             :         /*
     820             :          * Check to see if my copy of RedoRecPtr is out of date. If so, may
     821             :          * have to go back and have the caller recompute everything. This can
     822             :          * only happen just after a checkpoint, so it's better to be slow in
     823             :          * this case and fast otherwise.
     824             :          *
     825             :          * Also check to see if fullPageWrites was just turned on or there's a
     826             :          * running backup (which forces full-page writes); if we weren't
     827             :          * already doing full-page writes then go back and recompute.
     828             :          *
     829             :          * If we aren't doing full-page writes then RedoRecPtr doesn't
     830             :          * actually affect the contents of the XLOG record, so we'll update
     831             :          * our local copy but not force a recomputation.  (If doPageWrites was
     832             :          * just turned off, we could recompute the record without full pages,
     833             :          * but we choose not to bother.)
     834             :          */
     835    24794814 :         if (RedoRecPtr != Insert->RedoRecPtr)
     836             :         {
     837        9472 :             Assert(RedoRecPtr < Insert->RedoRecPtr);
     838        9472 :             RedoRecPtr = Insert->RedoRecPtr;
     839             :         }
     840    24794814 :         doPageWrites = (Insert->fullPageWrites || Insert->runningBackups > 0);
     841             : 
     842    24794814 :         if (doPageWrites &&
     843    24372760 :             (!prevDoPageWrites ||
     844    23242898 :              (fpw_lsn != InvalidXLogRecPtr && fpw_lsn <= RedoRecPtr)))
     845             :         {
     846             :             /*
     847             :              * Oops, some buffer now needs to be backed up that the caller
     848             :              * didn't back up.  Start over.
     849             :              */
     850       10576 :             WALInsertLockRelease();
     851       10576 :             END_CRIT_SECTION();
     852       10576 :             return InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     853             :         }
     854             : 
     855             :         /*
     856             :          * Reserve space for the record in the WAL. This also sets the xl_prev
     857             :          * pointer.
     858             :          */
     859    24784238 :         ReserveXLogInsertLocation(rechdr->xl_tot_len, &StartPos, &EndPos,
     860             :                                   &rechdr->xl_prev);
     861             : 
     862             :         /* Normal records are always inserted. */
     863    24784238 :         inserted = true;
     864             :     }
     865        1216 :     else if (class == WALINSERT_SPECIAL_SWITCH)
     866             :     {
     867             :         /*
     868             :          * In order to insert an XLOG_SWITCH record, we need to hold all of
     869             :          * the WAL insertion locks, not just one, so that no one else can
     870             :          * begin inserting a record until we've figured out how much space
     871             :          * remains in the current WAL segment and claimed all of it.
     872             :          *
     873             :          * Nonetheless, this case is simpler than the normal cases handled
     874             :          * below, which must check for changes in doPageWrites and RedoRecPtr.
     875             :          * Those checks are only needed for records that can contain buffer
     876             :          * references, and an XLOG_SWITCH record never does.
     877             :          */
     878         624 :         Assert(fpw_lsn == InvalidXLogRecPtr);
     879         624 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
     880         624 :         inserted = ReserveXLogSwitch(&StartPos, &EndPos, &rechdr->xl_prev);
     881             :     }
     882             :     else
     883             :     {
     884         592 :         Assert(class == WALINSERT_SPECIAL_CHECKPOINT);
     885             : 
     886             :         /*
     887             :          * We need to update both the local and shared copies of RedoRecPtr,
     888             :          * which means that we need to hold all the WAL insertion locks.
     889             :          * However, there can't be any buffer references, so as above, we need
     890             :          * not check RedoRecPtr before inserting the record; we just need to
     891             :          * update it afterwards.
     892             :          */
     893         592 :         Assert(fpw_lsn == InvalidXLogRecPtr);
     894         592 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
     895         592 :         ReserveXLogInsertLocation(rechdr->xl_tot_len, &StartPos, &EndPos,
     896             :                                   &rechdr->xl_prev);
     897         592 :         RedoRecPtr = Insert->RedoRecPtr = StartPos;
     898         592 :         inserted = true;
     899             :     }
     900             : 
     901    24785454 :     if (inserted)
     902             :     {
     903             :         /*
     904             :          * Now that xl_prev has been filled in, calculate CRC of the record
     905             :          * header.
     906             :          */
     907    24785366 :         rdata_crc = rechdr->xl_crc;
     908    24785366 :         COMP_CRC32C(rdata_crc, rechdr, offsetof(XLogRecord, xl_crc));
     909    24785366 :         FIN_CRC32C(rdata_crc);
     910    24785366 :         rechdr->xl_crc = rdata_crc;
     911             : 
     912             :         /*
     913             :          * All the record data, including the header, is now ready to be
     914             :          * inserted. Copy the record in the space reserved.
     915             :          */
     916    24785366 :         CopyXLogRecordToWAL(rechdr->xl_tot_len,
     917             :                             class == WALINSERT_SPECIAL_SWITCH, rdata,
     918             :                             StartPos, EndPos, insertTLI);
     919             : 
     920             :         /*
     921             :          * Unless record is flagged as not important, update LSN of last
     922             :          * important record in the current slot. When holding all locks, just
     923             :          * update the first one.
     924             :          */
     925    24785366 :         if ((flags & XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT) == 0)
     926             :         {
     927    24648180 :             int         lockno = holdingAllLocks ? 0 : MyLockNo;
     928             : 
     929    24648180 :             WALInsertLocks[lockno].l.lastImportantAt = StartPos;
     930             :         }
     931             :     }
     932             :     else
     933             :     {
     934             :         /*
     935             :          * This was an xlog-switch record, but the current insert location was
     936             :          * already exactly at the beginning of a segment, so there was no need
     937             :          * to do anything.
     938             :          */
     939             :     }
     940             : 
     941             :     /*
     942             :      * Done! Let others know that we're finished.
     943             :      */
     944    24785454 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
     945             : 
     946    24785454 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
     947             : 
     948    24785454 :     MarkCurrentTransactionIdLoggedIfAny();
     949             : 
     950             :     /*
     951             :      * Mark top transaction id is logged (if needed) so that we should not try
     952             :      * to log it again with the next WAL record in the current subtransaction.
     953             :      */
     954    24785454 :     if (topxid_included)
     955         434 :         MarkSubxactTopXidLogged();
     956             : 
     957             :     /*
     958             :      * Update shared LogwrtRqst.Write, if we crossed page boundary.
     959             :      */
     960    24785454 :     if (StartPos / XLOG_BLCKSZ != EndPos / XLOG_BLCKSZ)
     961             :     {
     962      530988 :         SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
     963             :         /* advance global request to include new block(s) */
     964      530988 :         if (XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write < EndPos)
     965      530764 :             XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write = EndPos;
     966             :         /* update local result copy while I have the chance */
     967      530988 :         LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
     968      530988 :         SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
     969             :     }
     970             : 
     971             :     /*
     972             :      * If this was an XLOG_SWITCH record, flush the record and the empty
     973             :      * padding space that fills the rest of the segment, and perform
     974             :      * end-of-segment actions (eg, notifying archiver).
     975             :      */
     976    24785454 :     if (class == WALINSERT_SPECIAL_SWITCH)
     977             :     {
     978         624 :         TRACE_POSTGRESQL_WAL_SWITCH();
     979         624 :         XLogFlush(EndPos);
     980             : 
     981             :         /*
     982             :          * Even though we reserved the rest of the segment for us, which is
     983             :          * reflected in EndPos, we return a pointer to just the end of the
     984             :          * xlog-switch record.
     985             :          */
     986         624 :         if (inserted)
     987             :         {
     988         536 :             EndPos = StartPos + SizeOfXLogRecord;
     989         536 :             if (StartPos / XLOG_BLCKSZ != EndPos / XLOG_BLCKSZ)
     990             :             {
     991           0 :                 uint64      offset = XLogSegmentOffset(EndPos, wal_segment_size);

     993           0 :                 if (offset == EndPos % XLOG_BLCKSZ)
     994           0 :                     EndPos += SizeOfXLogLongPHD;

     996           0 :                     EndPos += SizeOfXLogShortPHD;

    1083             : 
    1084             : /*
    1085             :  * Reserves the right amount of space for a record of given size from the WAL.
    1086             :  * *StartPos is set to the beginning of the reserved section, *EndPos to
    1087             :  * its end+1. *PrevPtr is set to the beginning of the previous record; it is
    1088             :  * used to set the xl_prev of this record.
    1089             :  *
    1090             :  * This is the performance critical part of XLogInsert that must be serialized
    1091             :  * across backends. The rest can happen mostly in parallel. Try to keep this
    1092             :  * section as short as possible, insertpos_lck can be heavily contended on a
    1093             :  * busy system.
    1094             :  *
    1095             :  * NB: The space calculation here must match the code in CopyXLogRecordToWAL,
    1096             :  * where we actually copy the record to the reserved space.
    1097             :  *
    1098             :  * NB: Testing shows that XLogInsertRecord runs faster if this code is inlined;
    1099             :  * however, because there are two call sites, the compiler is reluctant to
    1100             :  * inline. We use pg_attribute_always_inline here to try to convince it.
    1101             :  */
    1102             : static pg_attribute_always_inline void
    1103    24784830 : ReserveXLogInsertLocation(int size, XLogRecPtr *StartPos, XLogRecPtr *EndPos,
    1104             :                           XLogRecPtr *PrevPtr)
    1105             : {
    1106    24784830 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    1107             :     uint64      startbytepos;
    1108             :     uint64      endbytepos;
    1109             :     uint64      prevbytepos;
    1110             : 
    1111    24784830 :     size = MAXALIGN(size);
    1112             : 
    1113             :     /* All (non xlog-switch) records should contain data. */
    1114    24784830 :     Assert(size > SizeOfXLogRecord);
    1115             : 
    1116             :     /*
    1117             :      * The duration the spinlock needs to be held is minimized by minimizing
    1118             :      * the calculations that have to be done while holding the lock. The
    1119             :      * current tip of reserved WAL is kept in CurrBytePos, as a byte position
    1120             :      * that only counts "usable" bytes in WAL, that is, it excludes all WAL
    1121             :      * page headers. The mapping between "usable" byte positions and physical
    1122             :      * positions (XLogRecPtrs) can be done outside the locked region, and
    1123             :      * because the usable byte position doesn't include any headers, reserving
    1124             :      * X bytes from WAL is almost as simple as "CurrBytePos += X".
    1125             :      */
    1126    24784830 :     SpinLockAcquire(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1127             : 
    1128    24784830 :     startbytepos = Insert->CurrBytePos;
    1129    24784830 :     endbytepos = startbytepos + size;
    1130    24784830 :     prevbytepos = Insert->PrevBytePos;
    1131    24784830 :     Insert->CurrBytePos = endbytepos;
    1132    24784830 :     Insert->PrevBytePos = startbytepos;
    1133             : 
    1134    24784830 :     SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1135             : 
    1136    24784830 :     *StartPos = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(startbytepos);
    1137    24784830 :     *EndPos = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(endbytepos);
    1138    24784830 :     *PrevPtr = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(prevbytepos);
    1139             : 
    1140             :     /*
    1141             :      * Check that the conversions between "usable byte positions" and
    1142             :      * XLogRecPtrs work consistently in both directions.
    1143             :      */
    1144    24784830 :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*StartPos) == startbytepos);
    1145    24784830 :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*EndPos) == endbytepos);
    1146    24784830 :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*PrevPtr) == prevbytepos);
    1147    24784830 : }
    1148             : 
    1149             : /*
    1150             :  * Like ReserveXLogInsertLocation(), but for an xlog-switch record.
    1151             :  *
    1152             :  * A log-switch record is handled slightly differently. The rest of the
    1153             :  * segment will be reserved for this insertion, as indicated by the returned
    1154             :  * *EndPos value. However, if we are already at the beginning of the current
    1155             :  * segment, *StartPos and *EndPos are set to the current location without
    1156             :  * reserving any space, and the function returns false.
    1157             : */
    1158             : static bool
    1159         624 : ReserveXLogSwitch(XLogRecPtr *StartPos, XLogRecPtr *EndPos, XLogRecPtr *PrevPtr)
    1160             : {
    1161         624 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    1162             :     uint64      startbytepos;
    1163             :     uint64      endbytepos;
    1164             :     uint64      prevbytepos;
    1165         624 :     uint32      size = MAXALIGN(SizeOfXLogRecord);
    1166             :     XLogRecPtr  ptr;
    1167             :     uint32      segleft;
    1168             : 
    1169             :     /*
    1170             :      * These calculations are a bit heavy-weight to be done while holding a
    1171             :      * spinlock, but since we're holding all the WAL insertion locks, there
    1172             :      * are no other inserters competing for it. GetXLogInsertRecPtr() does
    1173             :      * compete for it, but that's not called very frequently.
    1174             :      */
    1175         624 :     SpinLockAcquire(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1176             : 
    1177         624 :     startbytepos = Insert->CurrBytePos;
    1178             :

    1181             :     {
    1182          88 :         SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1183          88 :         *EndPos = *StartPos = ptr;
    1184          88 :         return false;
    1185             :     }
    1186             : 
    1187         536 :     endbytepos = startbytepos + size;

    1189             :

    1191         536 :     *EndPos = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(endbytepos);
    1192             : 
    1193         536 :     segleft = wal_segment_size - XLogSegmentOffset(*EndPos, wal_segment_size);

    1195             :     {
    1196             :         /* consume the rest of the segment */
    1197         536 :         *EndPos += segleft;
    1198         536 :         endbytepos = XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*EndPos);

    1203         536 :     SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);

    1205         536 :     *PrevPtr = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(prevbytepos);
    1206             : 
    1207         536 :     Assert(XLogSegmentOffset(*EndPos, wal_segment_size) == 0);
    1208         536 :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*EndPos) == endbytepos);
    1209         536 :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*StartPos) == startbytepos);
    1210         536 :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*PrevPtr) == prevbytepos);
    1211             : 
    1212         536 :     return true;
