    1303             :      * we also have to consume all the remaining space in the WAL segment.  We
    1304             :      * have already reserved that space, but we need to actually fill it.
    1305             :      */
    1306    24785366 :     if (isLogSwitch && XLogSegmentOffset(CurrPos, wal_segment_size) != 0)
    1307             :     {
    1308             :         /* An xlog-switch record doesn't contain any data besides the header */
    1309         536 :         Assert(write_len == SizeOfXLogRecord);
    1310             : 
    1311             :         /* Assert that we did reserve the right amount of space */
    1312         536 :         Assert(XLogSegmentOffset(EndPos, wal_segment_size) == 0);
    1313             : 
    1314             :         /* Use up all the remaining space on the current page */
    1315         536 :         CurrPos += freespace;
    1316             : 
    1317             :         /*
    1318             :          * Cause all remaining pages in the segment to be flushed, leaving the
    1319             :          * XLog position where it should be, at the start of the next segment.
    1320             :          * We do this one page at a time, to make sure we don't deadlock
    1321             :          * against ourselves if wal_buffers < wal_segment_size.
    1322             :          */
    1323      842700 :         while (CurrPos < EndPos)
    1324             :         {
    1325             :             /*
    1326             :              * The minimal action to flush the page would be to call
    1327             :              * WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(CurrPos) followed by
    1328             :              * AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(...).  The page would be left initialized
    1329             :              * mostly to zeros, except for the page header (always the short
    1330             :              * variant, as this is never a segment's first page).
    1331             :              *
    1332             :              * The large vistas of zeros are good for compressibility, but the
    1333             :              * headers interrupting them every XLOG_BLCKSZ (with values that
    1334             :              * differ from page to page) are not.  The effect varies with
    1335             :              * compression tool, but bzip2 for instance compresses about an
    1336             :              * order of magnitude worse if those headers are left in place.
    1337             :              *
    1338             :              * Rather than complicating AdvanceXLInsertBuffer itself (which is
    1339             :              * called in heavily-loaded circumstances as well as this lightly-
    1340             :              * loaded one) with variant behavior, we just use GetXLogBuffer
    1341             :              * (which itself calls the two methods we need) to get the pointer
    1342             :              * and zero most of the page.  Then we just zero the page header.
    1343             :              */
    1344      842164 :             currpos = GetXLogBuffer(CurrPos, tli);
    1345     3368656 :             MemSet(currpos, 0, SizeOfXLogShortPHD);
    1346             : 
    1347      842164 :             CurrPos += XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1348             :         }
    1349             :     }
    1350             :     else
    1351             :     {
    1352             :         /* Align the end position, so that the next record starts aligned */
    1353    24784830 :         CurrPos = MAXALIGN64(CurrPos);
    1354             :     }
    1355             : 
    1356    24785366 :     if (CurrPos != EndPos)
    1357           0 :         elog(PANIC, "space reserved for WAL record does not match what was written");
    1358    24785366 : }
    1359             : 
    1360             : /*
    1361             :  * Acquire a WAL insertion lock, for inserting to WAL.
    1362             :  */
    1363             : static void
    1364    24794834 : WALInsertLockAcquire(void)
    1365             : {
    1366             :     bool        immed;
    1367             : 
    1368             :     /*
    1369             :      * It doesn't matter which of the WAL insertion locks we acquire, so try
    1370             :      * the one we used last time.  If the system isn't particularly busy, it's
    1371             :      * a good bet that it's still available, and it's good to have some
    1372             :      * affinity to a particular lock so that you don't unnecessarily bounce
    1373             :      * cache lines between processes when there's no contention.
    1374             :      *
    1375             :      * If this is the first time through in this backend, pick a lock
    1376             :      * (semi-)randomly.  This allows the locks to be used evenly if you have a
    1377             :      * lot of very short connections.
    1378             :      */
    1379             :     static int  lockToTry = -1;
    1380             : 
    1381    24794834 :     if (lockToTry == -1)
    1382       11540 :         lockToTry = MyProc->pgprocno % NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS;
    1383    24794834 :     MyLockNo = lockToTry;
    1384             : 
    1385             :     /*
    1386             :      * The insertingAt value is initially set to 0, as we don't know our
    1387             :      * insert location yet.
    1388             :      */
    1389    24794834 :     immed = LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1390    24794834 :     if (!immed)
    1391             :     {
    1392             :         /*
    1393             :          * If we couldn't get the lock immediately, try another lock next
    1394             :          * time.  On a system with more insertion locks than concurrent
    1395             :          * inserters, this causes all the inserters to eventually migrate to a
    1396             :          * lock that no-one else is using.  On a system with more inserters
    1397             :          * than locks, it still helps to distribute the inserters evenly
    1398             :          * across the locks.
    1399             :          */
    1400        1810 :         lockToTry = (lockToTry + 1) % NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS;
    1401             :     }
    1402    24794834 : }
    1403             : 
    1404             : /*
    1405             :  * Acquire all WAL insertion locks, to prevent other backends from inserting
    1406             :  * to WAL.
    1407             :  */
    1408             : static void
    1409        4136 : WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive(void)
    1410             : {
    1411             :     int         i;
    1412             : 
    1413             :     /*
    1414             :      * When holding all the locks, all but the last lock's insertingAt
    1415             :      * indicator is set to 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF, which is higher than any real
    1416             :      * XLogRecPtr value, to make sure that no-one blocks waiting on those.
    1417             :      */
    1418       33088 :     for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS - 1; i++)
    1419             :     {
    1420       28952 :         LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1421       28952 :         LWLockUpdateVar(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock,
    1422       28952 :                         &WALInsertLocks[i].l.insertingAt,
    1423             :                         PG_UINT64_MAX);
    1424             :     }
    1425             :     /* Variable value reset to 0 at release */
    1426        4136 :     LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1427             : 
    1428        4136 :     holdingAllLocks = true;
    1429        4136 : }
    1430             : 
    1431             : /*
    1432             :  * Release our insertion lock (or locks, if we're holding them all).
    1433             :  *
    1434             :  * NB: Reset all variables to 0, so they cause LWLockWaitForVar to block the
    1435             :  * next time the lock is acquired.
    1436             :  */
    1437             : static void
    1438    24798970 : WALInsertLockRelease(void)
    1439             : {
    1440    24798970 :     if (holdingAllLocks)
    1441             :     {
    1442             :         int         i;
    1443             : 
    1444       37224 :         for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS; i++)
    1445       33088 :             LWLockReleaseClearVar(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock,
    1446       33088 :                                   &WALInsertLocks[i].l.insertingAt,
    1447             :                                   0);
    1448             : 
    1449        4136 :         holdingAllLocks = false;
    1450             :     }
    1451             :     else
    1452             :     {
    1453    24794834 :         LWLockReleaseClearVar(&WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.lock,
    1454    24794834 :                               &WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.insertingAt,
    1455             :                               0);
    1456             :     }
    1457    24798970 : }
    1458             : 
    1459             : /*
    1460             :  * Update our insertingAt value, to let others know that we've finished
    1461             :  * inserting up to that point.
    1462             :  */
    1463             : static void
    1464     1263692 : WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(XLogRecPtr insertingAt)
    1465             : {
    1466     1263692 :     if (holdingAllLocks)
    1467             :     {
    1468             :         /*
    1469             :          * We use the last lock to mark our actual position, see comments in
    1470             :          * WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive.
    1471             :          */
    1472      838792 :         LWLockUpdateVar(&WALInsertLocks[NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS - 1].l.lock,
    1473      838792 :                         &WALInsertLocks[NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS - 1].l.insertingAt,
    1474             :                         insertingAt);
    1475             :     }
    1476             :     else
    1477      424900 :         LWLockUpdateVar(&WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.lock,
    1478      424900 :                         &WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.insertingAt,
    1479             :                         insertingAt);
    1480     1263692 : }
    1481             : 
    1482             : /*
    1483             :  * Wait for any WAL insertions < upto to finish.
    1484             :  *
    1485             :  * Returns the location of the oldest insertion that is still in-progress.
    1486             :  * Any WAL prior to that point has been fully copied into WAL buffers, and
    1487             :  * can be flushed out to disk. Because this waits for any insertions older
    1488             :  * than 'upto' to finish, the return value is always >= 'upto'.
    1489             :  *
    1490             :  * Note: When you are about to write out WAL, you must call this function
    1491             :  * *before* acquiring WALWriteLock, to avoid deadlocks. This function might
    1492             :  * need to wait for an insertion to finish (or at least advance to next
    1493             :  * uninitialized page), and the inserter might need to evict an old WAL buffer
    1494             :  * to make room for a new one, which in turn requires WALWriteLock.
    1495             :  */
    1496             : static XLogRecPtr
    1497     1132996 : WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(XLogRecPtr upto)
    1498             : {
    1499             :     uint64      bytepos;
    1500             :     XLogRecPtr  reservedUpto;
    1501             :     XLogRecPtr  finishedUpto;
    1502     1132996 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    1503             :     int         i;
    1504             : 
    1505     1132996 :     if (MyProc == NULL)
    1506           0 :         elog(PANIC, "cannot wait without a PGPROC structure");
    1507             : 
    1508             :     /* Read the current insert position */
    1509     1132996 :     SpinLockAcquire(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1510     1132996 :     bytepos = Insert->CurrBytePos;
    1511     1132996 :     SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1512     1132996 :     reservedUpto = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(bytepos);
    1513             : 
    1514             :     /*
    1515             :      * No-one should request to flush a piece of WAL that hasn't even been
    1516             :      * reserved yet. However, it can happen if there is a block with a bogus
    1517             :      * LSN on disk, for example. XLogFlush checks for that situation and
    1518             :      * complains, but only after the flush. Here we just assume that to mean
    1519             :      * that all WAL that has been reserved needs to be finished. In this
    1520             :      * corner-case, the return value can be smaller than 'upto' argument.
    1521             :      */
    1522     1132996 :     if (upto > reservedUpto)
    1523             :     {
    1524           0 :         ereport(LOG,
    1525             :                 (errmsg("request to flush past end of generated WAL; request %X/%X, current position %X/%X",
    1526             :                         LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(upto), LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(reservedUpto))));
    1527           0 :         upto = reservedUpto;
    1528             :     }
    1529             : 
    1530             :     /*
    1531             :      * Loop through all the locks, sleeping on any in-progress insert older
    1532             :      * than 'upto'.
    1533             :      *
    1534             :      * finishedUpto is our return value, indicating the point upto which all
    1535             :      * the WAL insertions have been finished. Initialize it to the head of
    1536             :      * reserved WAL, and as we iterate through the insertion locks, back it
    1537             :      * out for any insertion that's still in progress.
    1538             :      */
    1539     1132996 :     finishedUpto = reservedUpto;
    1540    10196964 :     for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS; i++)
    1541             :     {
    1542     9063968 :         XLogRecPtr  insertingat = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    1543             : 
    1544             :         do
    1545             :         {
    1546             :             /*
    1547             :              * See if this insertion is in progress.  LWLockWaitForVar will
    1548             :              * wait for the lock to be released, or for the 'value' to be set
    1549             :              * by a LWLockUpdateVar call.  When a lock is initially acquired,
    1550             :              * its value is 0 (InvalidXLogRecPtr), which means that we don't
    1551             :              * know where it's inserting yet.  We will have to wait for it. If
    1552             :              * it's a small insertion, the record will most likely fit on the
    1553             :              * same page and the inserter will release the lock without ever
    1554             :              * calling LWLockUpdateVar.  But if it has to sleep, it will
    1555             :              * advertise the insertion point with LWLockUpdateVar before
    1556             :              * sleeping.
    1557             :              *
    1558             :              * In this loop we are only waiting for insertions that started
    1559             :              * before WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish was called.  The lack of
    1560             :              * memory barriers in the loop means that we might see locks as
    1561             :              * "unused" that have since become used.  This is fine because
    1562             :              * they only can be used for later insertions that we would not
    1563             :              * want to wait on anyway.  Not taking a lock to acquire the
    1564             :              * current insertingAt value means that we might see older
    1565             :              * insertingAt values.  This is also fine, because if we read a
    1566             :              * value too old, we will add ourselves to the wait queue, which
    1567             :              * contains atomic operations.
    1568             :              */
    1569     9065696 :             if (LWLockWaitForVar(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock,
    1570     9065696 :                                  &WALInsertLocks[i].l.insertingAt,
    1571             :                                  insertingat, &insertingat))
    1572             :             {
    1573             :                 /* the lock was free, so no insertion in progress */
    1574     2609778 :                 insertingat = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    1575     2609778 :                 break;
    1576             :             }
    1577             : 
    1578             :             /*
    1579             :              * This insertion is still in progress. Have to wait, unless the
    1580             :              * inserter has proceeded past 'upto'.
    1581             :              */
    1582     6455918 :         } while (insertingat < upto);
    1583             : 
    1584     9063968 :         if (insertingat != InvalidXLogRecPtr && insertingat < finishedUpto)
    1585      939634 :             finishedUpto = insertingat;
    1586             :     }
    1587     1132996 :     return finishedUpto;
    1588             : }
    1589             : 
    1590             : /*
    1591             :  * Get a pointer to the right location in the WAL buffer containing the
    1592             :  * given XLogRecPtr.
    1593             :  *
    1594             :  * If the page is not initialized yet, it is initialized. That might require
    1595             :  * evicting an old dirty buffer from the buffer cache, which means I/O.
    1596             :  *
    1597             :  * The caller must ensure that the page containing the requested location
    1598             :  * isn't evicted yet, and won't be evicted. The way to ensure that is to
    1599             :  * hold onto a WAL insertion lock with the insertingAt position set to
    1600             :  * something <= ptr. GetXLogBuffer() will update insertingAt if it needs
    1601             :  * to evict an old page from the buffer. (This means that once you call
    1602             :  * GetXLogBuffer() with a given 'ptr', you must not access anything before
    1603             :  * that point anymore, and must not call GetXLogBuffer() with an older 'ptr'
    1604             :  * later, because older buffers might be recycled already)
    1605             :  */
    1606             : static char *
    1607    26260672 : GetXLogBuffer(XLogRecPtr ptr, TimeLineID tli)
    1608             : {
    1609             :     int         idx;
    1610             :     XLogRecPtr  endptr;
    1611             :     static uint64 cachedPage = 0;
    1612             :     static char *cachedPos = NULL;
    1613             :     XLogRecPtr  expectedEndPtr;
    1614             : 
    1615             :     /*
    1616             :      * Fast path for the common case that we need to access again the same
    1617             :      * page as last time.
    1618             :      */
    1619    26260672 :     if (ptr / XLOG_BLCKSZ == cachedPage)
    1620             :     {
    1621    24519154 :         Assert(((XLogPageHeader) cachedPos)->xlp_magic == XLOG_PAGE_MAGIC);
    1622    24519154 :         Assert(((XLogPageHeader) cachedPos)->xlp_pageaddr == ptr - (ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ));
    1623    24519154 :         return cachedPos + ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1624             :     }
    1625             : 
    1626             :     /*
    1627             :      * The XLog buffer cache is organized so that a page is always loaded to a
    1628             :      * particular buffer.  That way we can easily calculate the buffer a given
    1629             :      * page must be loaded into, from the XLogRecPtr alone.
    1630             :      */
    1631     1741518 :     idx = XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(ptr);
    1632             : 
    1633             :     /*
    1634             :      * See what page is loaded in the buffer at the moment. It could be the
    1635             :      * page we're looking for, or something older. It can't be anything newer
    1636             :      * - that would imply the page we're looking for has already been written
    1637             :      * out to disk and evicted, and the caller is responsible for making sure
    1638             :      * that doesn't happen.
    1639             :      *
    1640             :      * We don't hold a lock while we read the value. If someone is just about
    1641             :      * to initialize or has just initialized the page, it's possible that we
    1642             :      * get InvalidXLogRecPtr. That's ok, we'll grab the mapping lock (in
    1643             :      * AdvanceXLInsertBuffer) and retry if we see anything other than the page
    1644             :      * we're looking for.
    1645             :      */
    1646     1741518 :     expectedEndPtr = ptr;
    1647     1741518 :     expectedEndPtr += XLOG_BLCKSZ - ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1648             : 
    1649     1741518 :     endptr = pg_atomic_read_u64(&XLogCtl->xlblocks[idx]);
    1650     1741518 :     if (expectedEndPtr != endptr)
    1651             :     {
    1652             :         XLogRecPtr  initializedUpto;
    1653             : 
    1654             :         /*
    1655             :          * Before calling AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(), which can block, let others
    1656             :          * know how far we're finished with inserting the record.
    1657             :          *
    1658             :          * NB: If 'ptr' points to just after the page header, advertise a
    1659             :          * position at the beginning of the page rather than 'ptr' itself. If
    1660             :          * there are no other insertions running, someone might try to flush
    1661             :          * up to our advertised location. If we advertised a position after
    1662             :          * the page header, someone might try to flush the page header, even
    1663             :          * though page might actually not be initialized yet. As the first
    1664             :          * inserter on the page, we are effectively responsible for making
    1665             :          * sure that it's initialized, before we let insertingAt to move past
    1666             :          * the page header.
    1667             :          */
    1668     1263692 :         if (ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ == SizeOfXLogShortPHD &&
    1669       10942 :             XLogSegmentOffset(ptr, wal_segment_size) > XLOG_BLCKSZ)
    1670       10942 :             initializedUpto = ptr - SizeOfXLogShortPHD;
    1671     1252750 :         else if (ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ == SizeOfXLogLongPHD &&
    1672        1066 :                  XLogSegmentOffset(ptr, wal_segment_size) < XLOG_BLCKSZ)
    1673         356 :             initializedUpto = ptr - SizeOfXLogLongPHD;
    1674             :         else
    1675     1252394 :             initializedUpto = ptr;
    1676             : 
    1677     1263692 :         WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(initializedUpto);
    1678             : 
    1679     1263692 :         AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(ptr, tli, false);
    1680     1263692 :         endptr = pg_atomic_read_u64(&XLogCtl->xlblocks[idx]);
    1681             : 
    1682     1263692 :         if (expectedEndPtr != endptr)
    1683           0 :             elog(PANIC, "could not find WAL buffer for %X/%X",
    1684             :                  LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(ptr));
    1685             :     }
    1686             :     else
    1687             :     {
    1688             :         /*
    1689             :          * Make sure the initialization of the page is visible to us, and
    1690             :          * won't arrive later to overwrite the WAL data we write on the page.
    1691             :          */

    1693             :     }
    1694             : 
    1695             :     /*
    1696             :      * Found the buffer holding this page. Return a pointer to the right

    1701             : 
    1702     1741518 :     Assert(((XLogPageHeader) cachedPos)->xlp_magic == XLOG_PAGE_MAGIC);

    1704             : 
    1705     1741518 :     return cachedPos + ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1706             : }
    1707             : 
    1708             : /*
    1709             :  * Read WAL data directly from WAL buffers, if available. Returns the number
    1710             :  * of bytes read successfully.
    1711             :  *
    1712             :  * Fewer than 'count' bytes may be read if some of the requested WAL data has
    1713             :  * already been evicted from the WAL buffers, or if the caller requests data
    1714             :  * that is not yet available.
    1715             :  *
    1716             :  * No locks are taken.
    1717             :  *
    1718             :  * The 'tli' argument is only used as a convenient safety check so that
    1719             :  * callers do not read from WAL buffers on a historical timeline.
    1720             :  */
    1721             : Size
    1722       50550 : WALReadFromBuffers(char *dstbuf, XLogRecPtr startptr, Size count,
    1723             :                    TimeLineID tli)
    1724             : {
    1725       50550 :     char       *pdst = dstbuf;
    1726       50550 :     XLogRecPtr  recptr = startptr;
    1727             :     XLogRecPtr  upto;
    1728             :     Size        nbytes;
    1729             : 
    1730       50550 :     if (RecoveryInProgress() || tli != GetWALInsertionTimeLine())
    1731        1470 :         return 0;
    1732             : 
    1733       49080 :     Assert(!XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(startptr));
    1734             : 
    1735             :     /*
    1736             :      * Don't read past the available WAL data.
    1737             :      *
    1738             :      * Check using local copy of LogwrtResult. Ordinarily it's been updated by
    1739             :      * the caller when determining how far to read; but if not, it just means
    1740             :      * we'll read less data.
    1741             :      *
    1742             :      * XXX: the available WAL could be extended to the WAL insert pointer by
    1743             :      * calling WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish().
    1744             :      */
    1745       49080 :     upto = Min(startptr + count, LogwrtResult.Write);
    1746       49080 :     nbytes = upto - startptr;
    1747             : 
    1748             :     /*
    1749             :      * Loop through the buffers without a lock. For each buffer, atomically
    1750             :      * read and verify the end pointer, then copy the data out, and finally
    1751             :      * re-read and re-verify the end pointer.
    1752             :      *
    1753             :      * Once a page is evicted, it never returns to the WAL buffers, so if the
    1754             :      * end pointer matches the expected end pointer before and after we copy
    1755             :      * the data, then the right page must have been present during the data
    1756             :      * copy. Read barriers are necessary to ensure that the data copy actually
    1757             :      * happens between the two verification steps.
    1758             :      *
    1759             :      * If either verification fails, we simply terminate the loop and return
    1760             :      * with the data that had been already copied out successfully.
    1761             :      */
    1762      129118 :     while (nbytes > 0)
    1763             :     {
    1764       93082 :         uint32      offset = recptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1765       93082 :         int         idx = XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(recptr);
    1766             :         XLogRecPtr  expectedEndPtr;
    1767             :         XLogRecPtr  endptr;
    1768             :         const char *page;
    1769             :         const char *psrc;
    1770             :         Size        npagebytes;
    1771             : 
    1772             :         /*
    1773             :          * Calculate the end pointer we expect in the xlblocks array if the
    1774             :          * correct page is present.
    1775             :          */
    1776       93082 :         expectedEndPtr = recptr + (XLOG_BLCKSZ - offset);
    1777             : 
    1778             :         /*
    1779             :          * First verification step: check that the correct page is present in
    1780             :          * the WAL buffers.
    1781             :          */
    1782       93082 :         endptr = pg_atomic_read_u64(&XLogCtl->xlblocks[idx]);
    1783       93082 :         if (expectedEndPtr != endptr)
    1784       13044 :             break;
    1785             : 
    1786             :         /*
    1787             :          * The correct page is present (or was at the time the endptr was
    1788             :          * read; must re-verify later). Calculate pointer to source data and
    1789             :          * determine how much data to read from this page.
    1790             :          */
    1791       80038 :         page = XLogCtl->pages + idx * (Size) XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1792       80038 :         psrc = page + offset;
    1793       80038 :         npagebytes = Min(nbytes, XLOG_BLCKSZ - offset);
    1794             : 
    1795             :         /*
    1796             :          * Ensure that the data copy and the first verification step are not
    1797             :          * reordered.
    1798             :          */
    1799       80038 :         pg_read_barrier();
    1800             : 
    1801             :         /* data copy */
    1802       80038 :         memcpy(pdst, psrc, npagebytes);
    1803             : 
    1804             :         /*
    1805             :          * Ensure that the data copy and the second verification step are not
    1806             :          * reordered.

    1808       80038 :         pg_read_barrier();
    1809             : 
    1810             :         /*
    1811             :          * Second verification step: check that the page we read from wasn't
    1812             :          * evicted while we were copying the data.
    1813             :          */

    1815       80038 :         if (expectedEndPtr != endptr)
    1816           0 :             break;
    1817             : 
    1818       80038 :         pdst += npagebytes;
    1819       80038 :         recptr += npagebytes;
    1820       80038 :         nbytes -= npagebytes;
    1821             :     }
    1822             : 
    1823       49080 :     Assert(pdst - dstbuf <= count);
    1824             : 
    1825       49080 :     return pdst - dstbuf;
    1826             : }

    1828             : /*

    1866             : 
    1867             : /*
    1868             :  * Like XLogBytePosToRecPtr, but if the position is at a page boundary,

    1913             : /*
    1914             :  * Convert an XLogRecPtr to a "usable byte position".

    1916             : static uint64
    1917    74359122 : XLogRecPtrToBytePos(XLogRecPtr ptr)
    1918             : {
    1919             :     uint64      fullsegs;
    1920             :     uint32      fullpages;
    1921             :     uint32      offset;
    1922             :     uint64      result;
    1923             : 
    1924    74359122 :     XLByteToSeg(ptr, fullsegs, wal_segment_size);
    1925             : 
    1926    74359122 :     fullpages = (XLogSegmentOffset(ptr, wal_segment_size)) / XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1927    74359122 :     offset = ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1928             : 
    1929    74359122 :     if (fullpages == 0)
    1930             :     {

    1932      132662 :         if (offset > 0)
    1933             :         {
    1934      131544 :             Assert(offset >= SizeOfXLogLongPHD);
    1935      131544 :             result += offset - SizeOfXLogLongPHD;
    1936             :         }
    1937             :     }
    1938             :     else
    1939             :     {
    1940    74226460 :         result = fullsegs * UsableBytesInSegment +
    1941    74226460 :             (XLOG_BLCKSZ - SizeOfXLogLongPHD) + /* account for first page */
    1942    74226460 :             (fullpages - 1) * UsableBytesInPage;    /* full pages */
    1943    74226460 :         if (offset > 0)
    1944             :         {
    1945    74202126 :             Assert(offset >= SizeOfXLogShortPHD);
    1946    74202126 :             result += offset - SizeOfXLogShortPHD;
    1947             :         }
    1948             :     }
    1949             : 
    1950    74359122 :     return result;
    1951             : }
    1952             : 
    1953             : /*
    1954             :  * Initialize XLOG buffers, writing out old buffers if they still contain
    1955             :  * unwritten data, upto the page containing 'upto'. Or if 'opportunistic' is
    1956             :  * true, initialize as many pages as we can without having to write out
    1957             :  * unwritten data. Any new pages are initialized to zeros, with pages headers
    1958             :  * initialized properly.
    1959             :  */
    1960             : static void
    1961     1266032 : AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(XLogRecPtr upto, TimeLineID tli, bool opportunistic)
    1962             : {
    1963     1266032 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;

    1968             :     XLogRecPtr  NewPageBeginPtr;
    1969             :     XLogPageHeader NewPage;
    1970     1266032 :     int         npages pg_attribute_unused() = 0;
    1971             : 
    1972     1266032 :     LWLockAcquire(WALBufMappingLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1973             : 
    1974             :     /*
    1975             :      * Now that we have the lock, check if someone initialized the page
    1976             :      * already.
    1977             :      */

    1979             :     {
    1980     2507378 :         nextidx = XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(XLogCtl->InitializedUpTo);
    1981             : 
    1982             :         /*

    1985             :          * already written out.
    1986             :          */

    1989             :         {

    2084             :          * blocks.  This allows the WAL archiver to know whether it is safe to
    2085             :          * compress archived WAL data by transforming full-block records into
    2086             :          * the non-full-block format.  It is sufficient to record this at the
    2087             :          * page level because we force a page switch (in fact a segment
    2088             :          * switch) when starting a backup, so the flag will be off before any
    2089             :          * records can be written during the backup.  At the end of a backup,
    2090             :          * the last page will be marked as all unsafe when perhaps only part

    2133             : /*
    2134             :  * Calculate CheckPointSegments based on max_wal_size_mb and
    2135             :  * checkpoint_completion_target.
    2136             :  */
    2137             : static void
    2138       11818 : CalculateCheckpointSegments(void)
    2139             : {
    2140             :     double      target;
    2141             : 
    2142             :     /*-------
    2143             :      * Calculate the distance at which to trigger a checkpoint, to avoid
    2144             :      * exceeding max_wal_size_mb. This is based on two assumptions:
    2145             :      *
    2146             :      * a) we keep WAL for only one checkpoint cycle (prior to PG11 we kept
    2147             :      *    WAL for two checkpoint cycles to allow us to recover from the
    2148             :      *    secondary checkpoint if the first checkpoint failed, though we
    2149             :      *    only did this on the primary anyway, not on standby. Keeping just
    2150             :      *    one checkpoint simplifies processing and reduces disk space in
    2151             :      *    many smaller databases.)
    2152             :      * b) during checkpoint, we consume checkpoint_completion_target *
    2153             :      *    number of segments consumed between checkpoints.
    2154             :      *-------
    2155             :      */
    2156       11818 :     target = (double) ConvertToXSegs(max_wal_size_mb, wal_segment_size) /
    2157       11818 :         (1.0 + CheckPointCompletionTarget);
    2158             : 
    2159             :     /* round down */
    2160       11818 :     CheckPointSegments = (int) target;
    2161             : 
    2162       11818 :     if (CheckPointSegments < 1)
    2163          18 :         CheckPointSegments = 1;
    2164       11818 : }
    2165             : 
    2166             : void
    2167        8836 : assign_max_wal_size(int newval, void *extra)
    2168             : {
    2169        8836 :     max_wal_size_mb = newval;
    2170        8836 :     CalculateCheckpointSegments();

    2211             : /*
    2212             :  * At a checkpoint, how many WAL segments to recycle as preallocated future
    2213             :  * XLOG segments? Returns the highest segment that should be preallocated.
    2214             :  */
    2215             : static XLogSegNo
    2216        1476 : XLOGfileslop(XLogRecPtr lastredoptr)
    2217             : {
    2218             :     XLogSegNo   minSegNo;
    2219             :     XLogSegNo   maxSegNo;
    2220             :     double      distance;
    2221             :     XLogSegNo   recycleSegNo;
    2222             : 
    2223             :     /*
    2224             :      * Calculate the segment numbers that min_wal_size_mb and max_wal_size_mb
    2225             :      * correspond to. Always recycle enough segments to meet the minimum, and
    2226             :      * remove enough segments to stay below the maximum.
    2227             :      */
    2228        1476 :     minSegNo = lastredoptr / wal_segment_size +
    2229        1476 :         ConvertToXSegs(min_wal_size_mb, wal_segment_size) - 1;
    2230        1476 :     maxSegNo = lastredoptr / wal_segment_size +
    2231        1476 :         ConvertToXSegs(max_wal_size_mb, wal_segment_size) - 1;
    2232             : 
    2233             :     /*
    2234             :      * Between those limits, recycle enough segments to get us through to the
    2235             :      * estimated end of next checkpoint.
    2236             :      *
    2237             :      * To estimate where the next checkpoint will finish, assume that the
    2238             :      * system runs steadily consuming CheckPointDistanceEstimate bytes between
    2239             :      * every checkpoint.
    2240             :      */
    2241        1476 :     distance = (1.0 + CheckPointCompletionTarget) * CheckPointDistanceEstimate;
    2242             :     /* add 10% for good measure. */

    2244             : 
    2245        1476 :     recycleSegNo = (XLogSegNo) ceil(((double) lastredoptr + distance) /
    2246             :                                     wal_segment_size);
    2247             : 
    2248        1476 :     if (recycleSegNo < minSegNo)
    2249        1156 :         recycleSegNo = minSegNo;
    2250        1476 :     if (recycleSegNo > maxSegNo)
    2251         128 :         recycleSegNo = maxSegNo;
    2252             : 
    2253        1476 :     return recycleSegNo;
    2254             : }
    2255             : 
    2256             : /*
    2257             :  * Check whether we've consumed enough xlog space that a checkpoint is needed.
    2258             :  *
    2259             :  * new_segno indicates a log file that has just been filled up (or read
    2260             :  * during recovery). We measure the distance from RedoRecPtr to new_segno
    2261             :  * and see if that exceeds CheckPointSegments.
    2262             :  *
    2263             :  * Note: it is caller's responsibility that RedoRecPtr is up-to-date.

    2266        1808 : XLogCheckpointNeeded(XLogSegNo new_segno)

    2276             : 
    2277             : /*
    2278             :  * Write and/or fsync the log at least as far as WriteRqst indicates.
    2279             :  *
    2280             :  * If flexible == true, we don't have to write as far as WriteRqst, but
    2281             :  * may stop at any convenient boundary (such as a cache or logfile boundary).
    2282             :  * This option allows us to avoid uselessly issuing multiple writes when a
    2283             :  * single one would do.
    2284             :  *
    2285             :  * Must be called with WALWriteLock held. WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(WriteRqst)
    2286             :  * must be called before grabbing the lock, to make sure the data is ready to
    2287             :  * write.
    2288             :  */
    2289             : static void
    2290     1126306 : XLogWrite(XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst, TimeLineID tli, bool flexible)
    2291             : {
    2292             :     bool        ispartialpage;

    2299             : 
    2300             :     /* We should always be inside a critical section here */
    2301     1126306 :     Assert(CritSectionCount > 0);
    2302             : 
    2303             :     /*
    2304             :      * Update local LogwrtResult (caller probably did this already, but...)

    2306     1126306 :     LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    2307             : 
    2308             :     /*
    2309             :      * Since successive pages in the xlog cache are consecutively allocated,
    2310             :      * we can usually gather multiple pages together and issue just one
    2311             :      * write() call.  npages is the number of pages we have determined can be
    2312             :      * written together; startidx is the cache block index of the first one,
    2313             :      * and startoffset is the file offset at which it should go. The latter

    2315             :      * all of them to keep the compiler quiet.

    2655             : /*
    2656             :  * Advance minRecoveryPoint in control file.
    2657             :  *
    2658             :  * If we crash during recovery, we must reach this point again before the
    2659             :  * database is consistent.
    2660             :  *
    2661             :  * If 'force' is true, 'lsn' argument is ignored. Otherwise, minRecoveryPoint
    2662             :  * is only updated if it's not already greater than or equal to 'lsn'.
    2663             :  */
    2664             : static void
    2665      177654 : UpdateMinRecoveryPoint(XLogRecPtr lsn, bool force)
    2666             : {
    2667             :     /* Quick check using our local copy of the variable */
    2668      177654 :     if (!updateMinRecoveryPoint || (!force && lsn <= LocalMinRecoveryPoint))
    2669      164266 :         return;
    2670             : 
    2671             :     /*
    2672             :      * An invalid minRecoveryPoint means that we need to recover all the WAL,
    2673             :      * i.e., we're doing crash recovery.  We never modify the control file's
    2674             :      * value in that case, so we can short-circuit future checks here too. The
    2675             :      * local values of minRecoveryPoint and minRecoveryPointTLI should not be
    2676             :      * updated until crash recovery finishes.  We only do this for the startup
    2677             :      * process as it should not update its own reference of minRecoveryPoint
    2678             :      * until it has finished crash recovery to make sure that all WAL
    2679             :      * available is replayed in this case.  This also saves from extra locks
    2680             :      * taken on the control file from the startup process.
    2681             :      */
    2682       13388 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(LocalMinRecoveryPoint) && InRecovery)
    2683             :     {
    2684          62 :         updateMinRecoveryPoint = false;
    2685          62 :         return;

    2687             : 
    2688       13326 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);

    2701             :         /*
    2702             :          * To avoid having to update the control file too often, we update it
    2703             :          * all the way to the last record being replayed, even though 'lsn'
    2704             :          * would suffice for correctness.  This also allows the 'force' case
    2705             :          * to not need a valid 'lsn' value.
    2706             :          *
    2707             :          * Another important reason for doing it this way is that the passed
    2708             :          * 'lsn' value could be bogus, i.e., past the end of available WAL, if
    2709             :          * the caller got it from a corrupted heap page.  Accepting such a
    2710             :          * value as the min recovery point would prevent us from coming up at

    2738             : /*

    2768             : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG

    2773             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(LogwrtResult.Flush));
    2774             : #endif
    2775             : 
    2776      214958 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    2777             : 
    2778             :     /*
    2779             :      * Since fsync is usually a horribly expensive operation, we try to
    2780             :      * piggyback as much data as we can on each fsync: if we see any more data
    2781             :      * entered into the xlog buffer, we'll write and fsync that too, so that
    2782             :      * the final value of LogwrtResult.Flush is as large as possible. This
    2783             :      * gives us some chance of avoiding another fsync immediately after.
    2784             :      */
    2785             : 
    2786             :     /* initialize to given target; may increase below */
    2787      214958 :     WriteRqstPtr = record;
    2788             : 
    2789             :     /*
    2790             :      * Now wait until we get the write lock, or someone else does the flush
    2791             :      * for us.

    2793             :     for (;;)
    2794        2208 :     {
    2795             :         XLogRecPtr  insertpos;
    2796             :

    2804             :         /* done already? */

    2809             :          * Before actually performing the write, wait for all in-flight
    2810             :          * insertions to the pages we're about to write to finish.

    2812      194288 :         insertpos = WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(WriteRqstPtr);
    2813             : 
    2814             :         /*
    2815             :          * Try to get the write lock. If we can't get it immediately, wait
    2816             :          * until it's released, and recheck if we still need to do the flush
    2817             :          * or if the backend that held the lock did it for us already. This
    2818             :          * helps to maintain a good rate of group committing when the system
    2819             :          * is bottlenecked by the speed of fsyncing.
    2820             :          */
    2821      194288 :         if (!LWLockAcquireOrWait(WALWriteLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE))
    2822             :         {

    2838             : 
    2839             :         /*
    2840             :          * Sleep before flush! By adding a delay here, we may give further
    2841             :          * backends the opportunity to join the backlog of group commit
    2842             :          * followers; this can significantly improve transaction throughput,
    2843             :          * at the risk of increasing transaction latency.
    2844             :          *
    2845             :          * We do not sleep if enableFsync is not turned on, nor if there are
    2846             :          * fewer than CommitSiblings other backends with active transactions.
    2847             :          */

    2849           0 :             MinimumActiveBackends(CommitSiblings))
    2850             :         {
    2851           0 :             pg_usleep(CommitDelay);
    2852             : 
    2853             :             /*
    2854             :              * Re-check how far we can now flush the WAL. It's generally not
    2855             :              * safe to call WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish while holding
    2856             :              * WALWriteLock, because an in-progress insertion might need to
    2857             :              * also grab WALWriteLock to make progress. But we know that all
    2858             :              * the insertions up to insertpos have already finished, because
    2859             :              * that's what the earlier WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish() returned.
    2860             :              * We're only calling it again to allow insertpos to be moved
    2861             :              * further forward, not to actually wait for anyone.
    2862             :              */
    2863           0 :             insertpos = WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(insertpos);
    2864             :         }
    2865             : 
    2866             :         /* try to write/flush later additions to XLOG as well */
    2867      191346 :         WriteRqst.Write = insertpos;
    2868      191346 :         WriteRqst.Flush = insertpos;
    2869             : 
    2870      191346 :         XLogWrite(WriteRqst, insertTLI, false);
    2871             : 
    2872      191346 :         LWLockRelease(WALWriteLock);
    2873             :         /* done */
    2874      191346 :         break;
    2875             :     }
    2876             : 
    2877      214958 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    2878             : 
    2879             :     /* wake up walsenders now that we've released heavily contended locks */
    2880      214958 :     WalSndWakeupProcessRequests(true, !RecoveryInProgress());
    2881             : 
    2882             :     /*
    2883             :      * If we still haven't flushed to the request point then we have a
    2884             :      * problem; most likely, the requested flush point is past end of XLOG.
    2885             :      * This has been seen to occur when a disk page has a corrupted LSN.
    2886             :      *
    2887             :      * Formerly we treated this as a PANIC condition, but that hurts the
    2888             :      * system's robustness rather than helping it: we do not want to take down
    2889             :      * the whole system due to corruption on one data page.  In particular, if
    2890             :      * the bad page is encountered again during recovery then we would be
    2891             :      * unable to restart the database at all!  (This scenario actually
    2892             :      * happened in the field several times with 7.1 releases.)  As of 8.4, bad
    2893             :      * LSNs encountered during recovery are UpdateMinRecoveryPoint's problem;
    2894             :      * the only time we can reach here during recovery is while flushing the
    2895             :      * end-of-recovery checkpoint record, and we don't expect that to have a
    2896             :      * bad LSN.
    2897             :      *
    2898             :      * Note that for calls from xact.c, the ERROR will be promoted to PANIC
    2899             :      * since xact.c calls this routine inside a critical section.  However,
    2900             :      * calls from bufmgr.c are not within critical sections and so we will not
    2901             :      * force a restart for a bad LSN on a data page.
    2902             :      */
    2903      214958 :     if (LogwrtResult.Flush < record)
    2904           0 :         elog(ERROR,
    2905             :              "xlog flush request %X/%X is not satisfied --- flushed only to %X/%X",
    2906             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(record),
    2907             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(LogwrtResult.Flush));
    2908             : }
    2909             : 
    2910             : /*
    2911             :  * Write & flush xlog, but without specifying exactly where to.
    2912             :  *
    2913             :  * We normally write only completed blocks; but if there is nothing to do on
    2914             :  * that basis, we check for unwritten async commits in the current incomplete
    2915             :  * block, and write through the latest one of those.  Thus, if async commits
    2916             :  * are not being used, we will write complete blocks only.
    2917             :  *
    2918             :  * If, based on the above, there's anything to write we do so immediately. But
    2919             :  * to avoid calling fsync, fdatasync et. al. at a rate that'd impact
    2920             :  * concurrent IO, we only flush WAL every wal_writer_delay ms, or if there's
    2921             :  * more than wal_writer_flush_after unflushed blocks.
    2922             :  *
    2923             :  * We can guarantee that async commits reach disk after at most three
    2924             :  * wal_writer_delay cycles. (When flushing complete blocks, we allow XLogWrite
    2925             :  * to write "flexibly", meaning it can stop at the end of the buffer ring;
    2926             :  * this makes a difference only with very high load or long wal_writer_delay,
    2927             :  * but imposes one extra cycle for the worst case for async commits.)
    2928             :  *
    2929             :  * This routine is invoked periodically by the background walwriter process.
    2930             :  *
    2931             :  * Returns true if there was any work to do, even if we skipped flushing due
    2932             :  * to wal_writer_delay/wal_writer_flush_after.
    2933             :  */
    2934             : bool
    2935       13264 : XLogBackgroundFlush(void)
    2936             : {
    2937             :     XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst;
    2938       13264 :     bool        flexible = true;
    2939             :     static TimestampTz lastflush;
    2940             :     TimestampTz now;
    2941             :     int         flushblocks;
    2942             :     TimeLineID  insertTLI;
    2943             : 
    2944             :     /* XLOG doesn't need flushing during recovery */
    2945       13264 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    2946          16 :         return false;
    2947             : 
    2948             :     /*
    2949             :      * Since we're not in recovery, InsertTimeLineID is set and can't change,
    2950             :      * so we can read it without a lock.
    2951             :      */
    2952       13248 :     insertTLI = XLogCtl->InsertTimeLineID;
    2953             : 
    2954             :     /* read LogwrtResult and update local state */
    2955       13248 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);

    2957       13248 :     WriteRqst = XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst;
    2958       13248 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2959             : 
    2960             :     /* back off to last completed page boundary */
    2961       13248 :     WriteRqst.Write -= WriteRqst.Write % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    2962             :

    2968       11544 :         SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2969       11544 :         flexible = false;       /* ensure it all gets written */
    2970             :     }
    2971             :

    2983             :             {

    2986             :         }

    2988             :     }
    2989             : 
    2990             :     /*
    2991             :      * Determine how far to flush WAL, based on the wal_writer_delay and
    2992             :      * wal_writer_flush_after GUCs.
    2993             :      *
    2994             :      * Note that XLogSetAsyncXactLSN() performs similar calculation based on
    2995             :      * wal_writer_flush_after, to decide when to wake us up.  Make sure the
    2996             :      * logic is the same in both places if you change this.
    2997             :      */
    2998        2340 :     now = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    2999        2340 :     flushblocks =
    3000        2340 :         WriteRqst.Write / XLOG_BLCKSZ - LogwrtResult.Flush / XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    3001             : 
    3002        2340 :     if (WalWriterFlushAfter == 0 || lastflush == 0)
    3003             :     {
    3004             :         /* first call, or block based limits disabled */
    3005         308 :         WriteRqst.Flush = WriteRqst.Write;
    3006         308 :         lastflush = now;
    3007             :     }
    3008        2032 :     else if (TimestampDifferenceExceeds(lastflush, now, WalWriterDelay))
    3009             :     {
    3010             :         /*
    3011             :          * Flush the writes at least every WalWriterDelay ms. This is
    3012             :          * important to bound the amount of time it takes for an asynchronous
    3013             :          * commit to hit disk.
    3014             :          */
    3015        2004 :         WriteRqst.Flush = WriteRqst.Write;
    3016        2004 :         lastflush = now;
    3017             :     }
    3018          28 :     else if (flushblocks >= WalWriterFlushAfter)
    3019             :     {
    3020             :         /* exceeded wal_writer_flush_after blocks, flush */
    3021          22 :         WriteRqst.Flush = WriteRqst.Write;

    3023             :     }

    3027           6 :         WriteRqst.Flush = 0;

    3056             : 
    3057             :     /*
    3058             :      * Great, done. To take some work off the critical path, try to initialize
    3059             :      * as many of the no-longer-needed WAL buffers for future use as we can.

    3062             :

    3482             : 
    3483             : /*
    3484             :  * Install a new XLOG segment file as a current or future log segment.
    3485             :  *
    3486             :  * This is used both to install a newly-created segment (which has a temp
    3487             :  * filename while it's being created) and to recycle an old segment.
    3488             :  *
    3489             :  * *segno: identify segment to install as (or first possible target).
    3490             :  * When find_free is true, this is modified on return to indicate the
    3491             :  * actual installation location or last segment searched.
    3492             :  *
    3493             :  * tmppath: initial name of file to install.  It will be renamed into place.
    3494             :  *
    3495             :  * find_free: if true, install the new segment at the first empty segno
    3496             :  * number at or after the passed numbers.  If false, install the new segment
    3497             :  * exactly where specified, deleting any existing segment file there.
    3498             :  *
    3499             :  * max_segno: maximum segment number to install the new file as.  Fail if no
    3500             :  * free slot is found between *segno and max_segno. (Ignored when find_free
    3501             :  * is false.)
    3502             :  *
    3503             :  * tli: The timeline on which the new segment should be installed.
    3504             :  *
    3505             :  * Returns true if the file was installed successfully.  false indicates that
    3506             :  * max_segno limit was exceeded, the startup process has disabled this
    3507             :  * function for now, or an error occurred while renaming the file into place.
    3508             :  */
    3509             : static bool

    3616             : 
    3617             : /*
    3618             :  * Preallocate log files beyond the specified log endpoint.
    3619             :  *
    3620             :  * XXX this is currently extremely conservative, since it forces only one
    3621             :  * future log segment to exist, and even that only if we are 75% done with
    3622             :  * the current one.  This is only appropriate for very low-WAL-volume systems.
    3623             :  * High-volume systems will be OK once they've built up a sufficient set of
    3624             :  * recycled log segments, but the startup transient is likely to include
    3625             :  * a lot of segment creations by foreground processes, which is not so good.
    3626             :  *
    3627             :  * XLogFileInitInternal() can ereport(ERROR).  All known causes indicate big
    3628             :  * trouble; for example, a full filesystem is one cause.  The checkpoint WAL
    3629             :  * and/or ControlFile updates already completed.  If a RequestCheckpoint()
    3630             :  * initiated the present checkpoint and an ERROR ends this function, the
    3631             :  * command that called RequestCheckpoint() fails.  That's not ideal, but it's
    3632             :  * not worth contorting more functions to use caller-specified elevel values.
    3633             :  * (With or without RequestCheckpoint(), an ERROR forestalls some inessential
    3634             :  * reporting and resource reclamation.)
    3635             :  */
    3636             : static void
    3637        1902 : PreallocXlogFiles(XLogRecPtr endptr, TimeLineID tli)

    3661             : /*
    3662             :  * Throws an error if the given log segment has already been removed or
    3663             :  * recycled. The caller should only pass a segment that it knows to have
    3664             :  * existed while the server has been running, as this function always
    3665             :  * succeeds if no WAL segments have been removed since startup.
    3666             :  * 'tli' is only used in the error message.
    3667             :  *
    3668             :  * Note: this function guarantees to keep errno unchanged on return.
    3669             :  * This supports callers that use this to possibly deliver a better
    3670             :  * error message about a missing file, while still being able to throw
    3671             :  * a normal file-access error afterwards, if this does return.

    3801             : /*

    3804             :  * endptr is current (or recent) end of xlog, and lastredoptr is the

    3869             : 
    3870             : /*
    3871             :  * Recycle or remove WAL files that are not part of the given timeline's
    3872             :  * history.
    3873             :  *
    3874             :  * This is called during recovery, whenever we switch to follow a new
    3875             :  * timeline, and at the end of recovery when we create a new timeline. We
    3876             :  * wouldn't otherwise care about extra WAL files lying in pg_wal, but they
    3877             :  * might be leftover pre-allocated or recycled WAL segments on the old timeline
    3878             :  * that we haven't used yet, and contain garbage. If we just leave them in
    3879             :  * pg_wal, they will eventually be archived, and we can't let that happen.
    3880             :  * Files that belong to our timeline history are valid, because we have
    3881             :  * successfully replayed them, but from others we can't be sure.
    3882             :  *
    3883             :  * 'switchpoint' is the current point in WAL where we switch to new timeline,
    3884             :  * and 'newTLI' is the new timeline we switch to.
    3885             :  */
    3886             : void
    3887         102 : RemoveNonParentXlogFiles(XLogRecPtr switchpoint, TimeLineID newTLI)
    3888             : {
    3889             :     DIR        *xldir;
    3890             :     struct dirent *xlde;
    3891             :     char        switchseg[MAXFNAMELEN];
    3892             :     XLogSegNo   endLogSegNo;
    3893             :     XLogSegNo   switchLogSegNo;
    3894             :     XLogSegNo   recycleSegNo;
    3895             : 
    3896             :     /*
    3897             :      * Initialize info about where to begin the work.  This will recycle,
    3898             :      * somewhat arbitrarily, 10 future segments.
    3899             :      */
    3900         102 :     XLByteToPrevSeg(switchpoint, switchLogSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    3901         102 :     XLByteToSeg(switchpoint, endLogSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    3902         102 :     recycleSegNo = endLogSegNo + 10;
    3903             : 
    3904             :     /*
    3905             :      * Construct a filename of the last segment to be kept.
    3906             :      */

    3915             :     {

    3941             : 
    3942             : /*
    3943             :  * Recycle or remove a log file that's no longer needed.
    3944             :  *
    3945             :  * segment_de is the dirent structure of the segment to recycle or remove.
    3946             :  * recycleSegNo is the segment number to recycle up to.  endlogSegNo is
    3947             :  * the segment number of the current (or recent) end of WAL.
    3948             :  *
    3949             :  * endlogSegNo gets incremented if the segment is recycled so as it is not
    3950             :  * checked again with future callers of this function.
    3951             :  *
    3952             :  * insertTLI is the current timeline for XLOG insertion. Any recycled segments
    3953             :  * should be used for this timeline.
    3954             :  */
    3955             : static void
    3956        1182 : RemoveXlogFile(const struct dirent *segment_de,
    3957             :                XLogSegNo recycleSegNo, XLogSegNo *endlogSegNo,
    3958             :                TimeLineID insertTLI)
    3959             : {
    3960             :     char        path[MAXPGPATH];
    3961             : #ifdef WIN32
    3962             :     char        newpath[MAXPGPATH];
    3963             : #endif
    3964        1182 :     const char *segname = segment_de->d_name;
    3965             : 
    3966        1182 :     snprintf(path, MAXPGPATH, XLOGDIR "/%s", segname);
    3967             : 
    3968             :     /*
    3969             :      * Before deleting the file, see if it can be recycled as a future log
    3970             :      * segment. Only recycle normal files, because we don't want to recycle
    3971             :      * symbolic links pointing to a separate archive directory.
    3972             :      */
    3973        1182 :     if (wal_recycle &&
    3974        1182 :         *endlogSegNo <= recycleSegNo &&
    3975        2276 :         XLogCtl->InstallXLogFileSegmentActive && /* callee rechecks this */

    3977        1134 :         InstallXLogFileSegment(endlogSegNo, path,
    3978             :                                true, recycleSegNo, insertTLI))
    3979             :     {
    3980        1082 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    3981             :                 (errmsg_internal("recycled write-ahead log file \"%s\"",
    3982             :                                  segname)));
    3983        1082 :         CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled++;
    3984             :         /* Needn't recheck that slot on future iterations */
    3985        1082 :         (*endlogSegNo)++;
    3986             :     }
    3987             :     else
    3988             :     {
    3989             :         /* No need for any more future segments, or recycling failed ... */
    3990             :         int         rc;
    3991             : 
    3992         100 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    3993             :                 (errmsg_internal("removing write-ahead log file \"%s\"",
    3994             :                                  segname)));
    3995             : 
    3996             : #ifdef WIN32
    3997             : 
    3998             :         /*
    3999             :          * On Windows, if another process (e.g another backend) holds the file
    4000             :          * open in FILE_SHARE_DELETE mode, unlink will succeed, but the file
    4001             :          * will still show up in directory listing until the last handle is
    4002             :          * closed. To avoid confusing the lingering deleted file for a live
    4003             :          * WAL file that needs to be archived, rename it before deleting it.
    4004             :          *
    4005             :          * If another process holds the file open without FILE_SHARE_DELETE
    4006             :          * flag, rename will fail. We'll try again at the next checkpoint.
    4007             :          */
    4008             :         snprintf(newpath, MAXPGPATH, "%s.deleted", path);
    4009             :         if (rename(path, newpath) != 0)
    4010             :         {
    4011             :             ereport(LOG,
    4012             :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
    4013             :                      errmsg("could not rename file \"%s\": %m",
    4014             :                             path)));
    4015             :             return;
    4016             :         }
    4017             :         rc = durable_unlink(newpath, LOG);
    4018             : #else
    4019         100 :         rc = durable_unlink(path, LOG);
    4020             : #endif
    4021         100 :         if (rc != 0)
    4022             :         {
    4023             :             /* Message already logged by durable_unlink() */
    4024           0 :             return;
    4025             :         }
    4026         100 :         CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed++;

    4029        1182 :     XLogArchiveCleanup(segname);
    4030             : }
    4031             : 
    4032             : /*
    4033             :  * Verify whether pg_wal, pg_wal/archive_status, and pg_wal/summaries exist.
    4034             :  * If the latter do not exist, recreate them.
    4035             :  *
    4036             :  * It is not the goal of this function to verify the contents of these
    4037             :  * directories, but to help in cases where someone has performed a cluster
    4038             :  * copy for PITR purposes but omitted pg_wal from the copy.
    4039             :  *
    4040             :  * We could also recreate pg_wal if it doesn't exist, but a deliberate
    4041             :  * policy decision was made not to.  It is fairly common for pg_wal to be
    4042             :  * a symlink, and if that was the DBA's intent then automatically making a
    4043             :  * plain directory would result in degraded performance with no notice.
    4044             :  */

    4130             : 
    4131             : /*
    4132             :  * I/O routines for pg_control
    4133             :  *
    4134             :  * *ControlFile is a buffer in shared memory that holds an image of the
    4135             :  * contents of pg_control.  WriteControlFile() initializes pg_control
    4136             :  * given a preloaded buffer, ReadControlFile() loads the buffer from
    4137             :  * the pg_control file (during postmaster or standalone-backend startup),
    4138             :  * and UpdateControlFile() rewrites pg_control after we modify xlog state.
    4139             :  * InitControlFile() fills the buffer with initial values.
    4140             :  *
    4141             :  * For simplicity, WriteControlFile() initializes the fields of pg_control
    4142             :  * that are related to checking backend/database compatibility, and
    4143             :  * ReadControlFile() verifies they are correct.  We could split out the
    4144             :  * I/O and compatibility-check functions, but there seems no need currently.
    4145             :  */
    4146             : 
    4147             : static void
    4148          64 : InitControlFile(uint64 sysidentifier)
    4149             : {
    4150             :     char        mock_auth_nonce[MOCK_AUTH_NONCE_LEN];
    4151             : 
    4152             :     /*
    4153             :      * Generate a random nonce. This is used for authentication requests that
    4154             :      * will fail because the user does not exist. The nonce is used to create
    4155             :      * a genuine-looking password challenge for the non-existent user, in lieu
    4156             :      * of an actual stored password.
    4157             :      */
    4158          64 :     if (!pg_strong_random(mock_auth_nonce, MOCK_AUTH_NONCE_LEN))
    4159           0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    4160             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INTERNAL_ERROR),
    4161             :                  errmsg("could not generate secret authorization token")));
    4162             : 
    4163          64 :     memset(ControlFile, 0, sizeof(ControlFileData));
    4164             :     /* Initialize pg_control status fields */
    4165          64 :     ControlFile->system_identifier = sysidentifier;
    4166          64 :     memcpy(ControlFile->mock_authentication_nonce, mock_auth_nonce, MOCK_AUTH_NONCE_LEN);

    4168          64 :     ControlFile->unloggedLSN = FirstNormalUnloggedLSN;

    4213             :                 (char *) ControlFile,

    4218             :      * We write out PG_CONTROL_FILE_SIZE bytes into pg_control, zero-padding

    4501             : /*
    4502             :  * Returns a fake LSN for unlogged relations.
    4503             :  *
    4504             :  * Each call generates an LSN that is greater than any previous value
    4505             :  * returned. The current counter value is saved and restored across clean
    4506             :  * shutdowns, but like unlogged relations, does not survive a crash. This can
    4507             :  * be used in lieu of real LSN values returned by XLogInsert, if you need an
    4508             :  * LSN-like increasing sequence of numbers without writing any WAL.
    4509             :  */
    4510             : XLogRecPtr

    4517          66 :     nextUnloggedLSN = XLogCtl->unloggedLSN++;
    4518          66 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->ulsn_lck);
    4519             : 
    4520          66 :     return nextUnloggedLSN;
    4521             : }
    4522             : 
    4523             : /*
    4524             :  * Auto-tune the number of XLOG buffers.
    4525             :  *
    4526             :  * The preferred setting for wal_buffers is about 3% of shared_buffers, with
    4527             :  * a maximum of one XLOG segment (there is little reason to think that more
    4528             :  * is helpful, at least so long as we force an fsync when switching log files)
    4529             :  * and a minimum of 8 blocks (which was the default value prior to PostgreSQL
    4530             :  * 9.1, when auto-tuning was added).
    4531             :  *
    4532             :  * This should not be called until NBuffers has received its final value.
    4533             :  */
    4534             : static int
    4535        1520 : XLOGChooseNumBuffers(void)
    4536             : {
    4537             :     int         xbuffers;
    4538             : 
    4539        1520 :     xbuffers = NBuffers / 32;
    4540        1520 :     if (xbuffers > (wal_segment_size / XLOG_BLCKSZ))
    4541          42 :         xbuffers = (wal_segment_size / XLOG_BLCKSZ);
    4542        1520 :     if (xbuffers < 8)
    4543         640 :         xbuffers = 8;
    4544        1520 :     return xbuffers;
    4545             : }
    4546             : 
    4547             : /*
    4548             :  * GUC check_hook for wal_buffers

    4553             :     /*
    4554             :      * -1 indicates a request for auto-tune.

    4557             :     {

    4559             :          * If we haven't yet changed the boot_val default of -1, just let it
    4560             :          * be.  We'll fix it when XLOGShmemSize is called.
    4561             :          */
    4562        1580 :         if (XLOGbuffers == -1)
    4563        1580 :             return true;
    4564             : 
    4565             :         /* Otherwise, substitute the auto-tune value */
    4566           0 :         *newval = XLOGChooseNumBuffers();
    4567             :     }
    4568             : 
    4569             :     /*
    4570             :      * We clamp manually-set values to at least 4 blocks.  Prior to PostgreSQL

    4574             :      * helpful.)

    4577           0 :         *newval = 4;

    4667             : /*
    4668             :  * GUC assign_hook for wal_consistency_checking
    4669             :  */
    4670             : void
    4671        1584 : assign_wal_consistency_checking(const char *newval, void *extra)
    4672             : {
    4673             :     /*
    4674             :      * If some checks were deferred, it's possible that the checks will fail
    4675             :      * later during InitializeWalConsistencyChecking(). But in that case, the
    4676             :      * postmaster will exit anyway, so it's safe to proceed with the
    4677             :      * assignment.
    4678             :      *
    4679             :      * Any built-in resource managers specified are assigned immediately,
    4680             :      * which affects WAL created before shared_preload_libraries are
    4681             :      * processed. Any custom resource managers specified won't be assigned
    4682             :      * until after shared_preload_libraries are processed, but that's OK
    4683             :      * because WAL for a custom resource manager can't be written before the
    4684             :      * module is loaded anyway.
    4685             :      */
    4686        1584 :     wal_consistency_checking = extra;
    4687        1584 : }
    4688             : 
    4689             : /*
    4690             :  * InitializeWalConsistencyChecking: run after loading custom resource managers
    4691             :  *

    4693             :  * wal_consistency_checking GUC, processing was deferred.  Now that
    4694             :  * shared_preload_libraries have been loaded, process wal_consistency_checking
    4695             :  * again.
    4696             :  */
    4697             : void
