    4746             : 
    4747             : /*
    4748             :  * Read the control file, set respective GUCs.
    4749             :  *
    4750             :  * This is to be called during startup, including a crash recovery cycle,
    4751             :  * unless in bootstrap mode, where no control file yet exists.  As there's no
    4752             :  * usable shared memory yet (its sizing can depend on the contents of the
    4753             :  * control file!), first store the contents in local memory. XLOGShmemInit()
    4754             :  * will then copy it to shared memory later.
    4755             :  *
    4756             :  * reset just controls whether previous contents are to be expected (in the
    4757             :  * reset case, there's a dangling pointer into old shared memory), or not.
    4758             :  */
    4759             : void
    4760        1338 : LocalProcessControlFile(bool reset)
    4761             : {
    4762        1338 :     Assert(reset || ControlFile == NULL);
    4763        1338 :     ControlFile = palloc(sizeof(ControlFileData));
    4764        1338 :     ReadControlFile();
    4765        1338 : }
    4766             : 
    4767             : /*

    4770             :  * was originally configured on standby.
    4771             :  */
    4772             : WalLevel

    4778             : /*
    4779             :  * Initialization of shared memory for XLOG
    4780             :  */
    4781             : Size
    4782        4376 : XLOGShmemSize(void)
    4783             : {
    4784             :     Size        size;
    4785             : 
    4786             :     /*
    4787             :      * If the value of wal_buffers is -1, use the preferred auto-tune value.
    4788             :      * This isn't an amazingly clean place to do this, but we must wait till
    4789             :      * NBuffers has received its final value, and must do it before using the
    4790             :      * value of XLOGbuffers to do anything important.
    4791             :      *
    4792             :      * We prefer to report this value's source as PGC_S_DYNAMIC_DEFAULT.
    4793             :      * However, if the DBA explicitly set wal_buffers = -1 in the config file,
    4794             :      * then PGC_S_DYNAMIC_DEFAULT will fail to override that and we must force
    4795             :      * the matter with PGC_S_OVERRIDE.
    4796             :      */
    4797        4376 :     if (XLOGbuffers == -1)
    4798             :     {
    4799             :         char        buf[32];
    4800             : 
    4801        1520 :         snprintf(buf, sizeof(buf), "%d", XLOGChooseNumBuffers());
    4802        1520 :         SetConfigOption("wal_buffers", buf, PGC_POSTMASTER,
    4803             :                         PGC_S_DYNAMIC_DEFAULT);
    4804        1520 :         if (XLOGbuffers == -1)  /* failed to apply it? */
    4805           0 :             SetConfigOption("wal_buffers", buf, PGC_POSTMASTER,
    4806             :                             PGC_S_OVERRIDE);
    4807             :     }
    4808        4376 :     Assert(XLOGbuffers > 0);
    4809             : 
    4810             :     /* XLogCtl */
    4811        4376 :     size = sizeof(XLogCtlData);
    4812             : 
    4813             :     /* WAL insertion locks, plus alignment */
    4814        4376 :     size = add_size(size, mul_size(sizeof(WALInsertLockPadded), NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS + 1));
    4815             :     /* xlblocks array */
    4816        4376 :     size = add_size(size, mul_size(sizeof(pg_atomic_uint64), XLOGbuffers));
    4817             :     /* extra alignment padding for XLOG I/O buffers */
    4818        4376 :     size = add_size(size, Max(XLOG_BLCKSZ, PG_IO_ALIGN_SIZE));
    4819             :     /* and the buffers themselves */
    4820        4376 :     size = add_size(size, mul_size(XLOG_BLCKSZ, XLOGbuffers));
    4821             : 
    4822             :     /*
    4823             :      * Note: we don't count ControlFileData, it comes out of the "slop factor"
    4824             :      * added by CreateSharedMemoryAndSemaphores.  This lets us use this
    4825             :      * routine again below to compute the actual allocation size.
    4826             :      */
    4827             : 
    4828        4376 :     return size;
    4829             : }
    4830             : 
    4831             : void
    4832        1522 : XLOGShmemInit(void)

    4839             : 
    4840             : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG
    4841             : 
    4842             :     /*
    4843             :      * Create a memory context for WAL debugging that's exempt from the normal
    4844             :      * "no pallocs in critical section" rule. Yes, that can lead to a PANIC if
    4845             :      * an allocation fails, but wal_debug is not for production use anyway.
    4846             :      */
    4847             :     if (walDebugCxt == NULL)
    4848             :     {
    4849             :         walDebugCxt = AllocSetContextCreate(TopMemoryContext,
    4850             :                                             "WAL Debug",
    4851             :                                             ALLOCSET_DEFAULT_SIZES);

    4853             :     }
    4854             : #endif
    4855             : 
    4856             :

    4859             : 
    4860        1522 :     localControlFile = ControlFile;

    4863             :

    4939             : /*
    4940             :  * This func must be called ONCE on system install.  It creates pg_control
    4941             :  * and the initial XLOG segment.
    4942             :  */
    4943             : void
    4944          64 : BootStrapXLOG(void)
    4945             : {
    4946             :     CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    4947             :     char       *buffer;
    4948             :     XLogPageHeader page;
    4949             :     XLogLongPageHeader longpage;
    4950             :     XLogRecord *record;
    4951             :     char       *recptr;
    4952             :     uint64      sysidentifier;
    4953             :     struct timeval tv;
    4954             :     pg_crc32c   crc;
    4955             : 
    4956             :     /* allow ordinary WAL segment creation, like StartupXLOG() would */
    4957          64 :     SetInstallXLogFileSegmentActive();
    4958             : 
    4959             :     /*
    4960             :      * Select a hopefully-unique system identifier code for this installation.
    4961             :      * We use the result of gettimeofday(), including the fractional seconds
    4962             :      * field, as being about as unique as we can easily get.  (Think not to
    4963             :      * use random(), since it hasn't been seeded and there's no portable way
    4964             :      * to seed it other than the system clock value...)  The upper half of the
    4965             :      * uint64 value is just the tv_sec part, while the lower half contains the
    4966             :      * tv_usec part (which must fit in 20 bits), plus 12 bits from our current
    4967             :      * PID for a little extra uniqueness.  A person knowing this encoding can
    4968             :      * determine the initialization time of the installation, which could
    4969             :      * perhaps be useful sometimes.
    4970             :      */
    4971          64 :     gettimeofday(&tv, NULL);
    4972          64 :     sysidentifier = ((uint64) tv.tv_sec) << 32;
    4973          64 :     sysidentifier |= ((uint64) tv.tv_usec) << 12;
    4974          64 :     sysidentifier |= getpid() & 0xFFF;
    4975             : 
    4976             :     /* page buffer must be aligned suitably for O_DIRECT */
    4977          64 :     buffer = (char *) palloc(XLOG_BLCKSZ + XLOG_BLCKSZ);
    4978          64 :     page = (XLogPageHeader) TYPEALIGN(XLOG_BLCKSZ, buffer);
    4979          64 :     memset(page, 0, XLOG_BLCKSZ);
    4980             :

    5137             :

    5142             :      * boundary, startLogSegNo will be endLogSegNo + 1.

    5144          84 :     XLByteToPrevSeg(endOfLog, endLogSegNo, wal_segment_size);

    5194             : 
    5195             : /*
    5196             :  * Perform cleanup actions at the conclusion of archive recovery.
    5197             :  */
    5198             : static void
    5199          84 : CleanupAfterArchiveRecovery(TimeLineID EndOfLogTLI, XLogRecPtr EndOfLog,
    5200             :                             TimeLineID newTLI)
    5201             : {
    5202             :     /*
    5203             :      * Execute the recovery_end_command, if any.
    5204             :      */
    5205          84 :     if (recoveryEndCommand && strcmp(recoveryEndCommand, "") != 0)
    5206           4 :         ExecuteRecoveryCommand(recoveryEndCommand,
    5207             :                                "recovery_end_command",
    5208             :                                true,
    5209             :                                WAIT_EVENT_RECOVERY_END_COMMAND);
    5210             : 
    5211             :     /*
    5212             :      * We switched to a new timeline. Clean up segments on the old timeline.
    5213             :      *
    5214             :      * If there are any higher-numbered segments on the old timeline, remove
    5215             :      * them. They might contain valid WAL, but they might also be
    5216             :      * pre-allocated files containing garbage. In any case, they are not part
    5217             :      * of the new timeline's history so we don't need them.
    5218             :      */
    5219          84 :     RemoveNonParentXlogFiles(EndOfLog, newTLI);
    5220             : 
    5221             :     /*
    5222             :      * If the switch happened in the middle of a segment, what to do with the
    5223             :      * last, partial segment on the old timeline? If we don't archive it, and
    5224             :      * the server that created the WAL never archives it either (e.g. because
    5225             :      * it was hit by a meteor), it will never make it to the archive. That's
    5226             :      * OK from our point of view, because the new segment that we created with
    5227             :      * the new TLI contains all the WAL from the old timeline up to the switch
    5228             :      * point. But if you later try to do PITR to the "missing" WAL on the old
    5229             :      * timeline, recovery won't find it in the archive. It's physically
    5230             :      * present in the new file with new TLI, but recovery won't look there
    5231             :      * when it's recovering to the older timeline. On the other hand, if we
    5232             :      * archive the partial segment, and the original server on that timeline
    5233             :      * is still running and archives the completed version of the same segment
    5234             :      * later, it will fail. (We used to do that in 9.4 and below, and it
    5235             :      * caused such problems).
    5236             :      *
    5237             :      * As a compromise, we rename the last segment with the .partial suffix,
    5238             :      * and archive it. Archive recovery will never try to read .partial
    5239             :      * segments, so they will normally go unused. But in the odd PITR case,
    5240             :      * the administrator can copy them manually to the pg_wal directory
    5241             :      * (removing the suffix). They can be useful in debugging, too.
    5242             :      *
    5243             :      * If a .done or .ready file already exists for the old timeline, however,
    5244             :      * we had already determined that the segment is complete, so we can let
    5245             :      * it be archived normally. (In particular, if it was restored from the
    5246             :      * archive to begin with, it's expected to have a .done file).
    5247             :      */
    5248          84 :     if (XLogSegmentOffset(EndOfLog, wal_segment_size) != 0 &&
    5249          70 :         XLogArchivingActive())
    5250             :     {
    5251             :         char        origfname[MAXFNAMELEN];
    5252             :         XLogSegNo   endLogSegNo;
    5253             : 
    5254          14 :         XLByteToPrevSeg(EndOfLog, endLogSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    5255          14 :         XLogFileName(origfname, EndOfLogTLI, endLogSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    5256             : 
    5257          14 :         if (!XLogArchiveIsReadyOrDone(origfname))
    5258             :         {
    5259             :             char        origpath[MAXPGPATH];
    5260             :             char        partialfname[MAXFNAMELEN];
    5261             :             char        partialpath[MAXPGPATH];
    5262             : 
    5263           8 :             XLogFilePath(origpath, EndOfLogTLI, endLogSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    5264           8 :             snprintf(partialfname, MAXFNAMELEN, "%s.partial", origfname);
    5265           8 :             snprintf(partialpath, MAXPGPATH, "%s.partial", origpath);
    5266             : 
    5267             :             /*
    5268             :              * Make sure there's no .done or .ready file for the .partial
    5269             :              * file.
    5270             :              */
    5271           8 :             XLogArchiveCleanup(partialfname);
    5272             : 
    5273           8 :             durable_rename(origpath, partialpath, ERROR);
    5274           8 :             XLogArchiveNotify(partialfname);
    5275             :         }
    5276             :     }
    5277          84 : }
    5278             : 
    5279             : /*
    5280             :  * Check to see if required parameters are set high enough on this server
    5281             :  * for various aspects of recovery operation.
    5282             :  *
    5283             :  * Note that all the parameters which this function tests need to be
    5284             :  * listed in Administrator's Overview section in high-availability.sgml.
    5285             :  * If you change them, don't forget to update the list.
    5286             :  */

    5326             : 
    5327             : /*

    5434             : 
    5435             :     /*----------
    5436             :      * If we previously crashed, perform a couple of actions:
    5437             :      *
    5438             :      * - The pg_wal directory may still include some temporary WAL segments
    5439             :      *   used when creating a new segment, so perform some clean up to not
    5440             :      *   bloat this path.  This is done first as there is no point to sync
    5441             :      *   this temporary data.
    5442             :      *
    5443             :      * - There might be data which we had written, intending to fsync it, but
    5444             :      *   which we had not actually fsync'd yet.  Therefore, a power failure in
    5445             :      *   the near future might cause earlier unflushed writes to be lost, even
    5446             :      *   though more recent data written to disk from here on would be
    5447             :      *   persisted.  To avoid that, fsync the entire data directory.
    5448             :      */

    5551             :      * server to a different archive than the primary, it'd be good for all
    5552             :      * the history files to get archived there after failover, so that you can
    5553             :      * use one of the old timelines as a PITR target. Timeline history files
    5554             :      * are small, so it's better to copy them unnecessarily than not copy them

    5562             :      * taking any recovery action has the merit to discard any 2PC files that
    5563             :      * are newer than the first record to replay, saving from any conflicts at
    5564             :      * replay.  This avoids as well any subsequent scans when doing recovery
    5565             :      * of the on-disk two-phase data.

    5765             : 
    5766             :     /*
    5767             :      * When recovering from a backup (we are in recovery, and archive recovery
    5768             :      * was requested), complain if we did not roll forward far enough to reach
    5769             :      * the point where the database is consistent.  For regular online
    5770             :      * backup-from-primary, that means reaching the end-of-backup WAL record
    5771             :      * (at which point we reset backupStartPoint to be Invalid), for
    5772             :      * backup-from-replica (which can't inject records into the WAL stream),
    5773             :      * that point is when we reach the minRecoveryPoint in pg_control (which
    5774             :      * we purposefully copy last when backing up from a replica).  For
    5775             :      * pg_rewind (which creates a backup_label with a method of "pg_rewind")
    5776             :      * or snapshot-style backups (which don't), backupEndRequired will be set
    5777             :      * to false.

    5780             :      * LocalMinRecoveryPoint here, even though ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint
    5781             :      * might be further ahead --- ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint cannot have
    5782             :      * been advanced beyond the WAL we processed.
    5783             :      */
    5784        1244 :     if (InRecovery &&

    5804             :     }
    5805             : 
    5806             :     /*
    5807             :      * Reset unlogged relations to the contents of their INIT fork. This is
    5808             :      * done AFTER recovery is complete so as to include any unlogged relations
    5809             :      * created during recovery, but BEFORE recovery is marked as having
    5810             :      * completed successfully. Otherwise we'd not retry if any of the post
    5811             :      * end-of-recovery steps fail.
    5812             :      */
    5813        1244 :     if (InRecovery)
    5814         282 :         ResetUnloggedRelations(UNLOGGED_RELATION_INIT);
    5815             : 
    5816             :     /*

    5821        1244 :     oldestActiveXID = PrescanPreparedTransactions(NULL, NULL);

    5825             :      * timeline, which creates a new segment, and after the last ReadRecord().

    5828             : 
    5829             :     /*
    5830             :      * Consider whether we need to assign a new timeline ID.
    5831             :      *
    5832             :      * If we did archive recovery, we always assign a new ID.  This handles a
    5833             :      * couple of issues.  If we stopped short of the end of WAL during
    5834             :      * recovery, then we are clearly generating a new timeline and must assign
    5835             :      * it a unique new ID.  Even if we ran to the end, modifying the current
    5836             :      * last segment is problematic because it may result in trying to
    5837             :      * overwrite an already-archived copy of that segment, and we encourage
    5838             :      * DBAs to make their archive_commands reject that.  We can dodge the
    5839             :      * problem by making the new active segment have a new timeline ID.
    5840             :      *
    5841             :      * In a normal crash recovery, we can just extend the timeline we were in.
    5842             :      */
    5843        1244 :     newTLI = endOfRecoveryInfo->lastRecTLI;
    5844        1244 :     if (ArchiveRecoveryRequested)
    5845             :     {
    5846          84 :         newTLI = findNewestTimeLine(recoveryTargetTLI) + 1;
    5847          84 :         ereport(LOG,
    5848             :                 (errmsg("selected new timeline ID: %u", newTLI)));
    5849             : 
    5850             :         /*
    5851             :          * Make a writable copy of the last WAL segment.  (Note that we also

    5866             : 
    5867             :         /*
    5868             :          * Write the timeline history file, and have it archived. After this
    5869             :          * point (or rather, as soon as the file is archived), the timeline
    5870             :          * will appear as "taken" in the WAL archive and to any standby
    5871             :          * servers.  If we crash before actually switching to the new
    5872             :          * timeline, standby servers will nevertheless think that we switched
    5873             :          * to the new timeline, and will try to connect to the new timeline.
    5874             :          * To minimize the window for that, try to do as little as possible
    5875             :          * between here and writing the end-of-recovery record.

    6040             :     /*
    6041             :      * All done with end-of-recovery actions.
    6042             :      *
    6043             :      * Now allow backends to write WAL and update the control file status in
    6044             :      * consequence.  SharedRecoveryState, that controls if backends can write
    6045             :      * WAL, is updated while holding ControlFileLock to prevent other backends
    6046             :      * to look at an inconsistent state of the control file in shared memory.
    6047             :      * There is still a small window during which backends can write WAL and
    6048             :      * the control file is still referring to a system not in DB_IN_PRODUCTION
    6049             :      * state while looking at the on-disk control file.
    6050             :      *
    6051             :      * Also, we use info_lck to update SharedRecoveryState to ensure that
    6052             :      * there are no race conditions concerning visibility of other recent
    6053             :      * updates to shared memory.

    6069             :      * any session building a snapshot will not rely on KnownAssignedXids as

    6071             :      * particularly critical for prepared 2PC transactions, that would still

    6161             : 
    6162             : /*
    6163             :  * Perform whatever XLOG actions are necessary at end of REDO.
    6164             :  *
    6165             :  * The goal here is to make sure that we'll be able to recover properly if
    6166             :  * we crash again. If we choose to write a checkpoint, we'll write a shutdown
    6167             :  * checkpoint rather than an on-line one. This is not particularly critical,
    6168             :  * but since we may be assigning a new TLI, using a shutdown checkpoint allows
    6169             :  * us to have the rule that TLI only changes in shutdown checkpoints, which
    6170             :  * allows some extra error checking in xlog_redo.
    6171             :  */
    6172             : static bool
    6173         282 : PerformRecoveryXLogAction(void)
    6174             : {
    6175         282 :     bool        promoted = false;
    6176             : 
    6177             :     /*
    6178             :      * Perform a checkpoint to update all our recovery activity to disk.
    6179             :      *
    6180             :      * Note that we write a shutdown checkpoint rather than an on-line one.
    6181             :      * This is not particularly critical, but since we may be assigning a new
    6182             :      * TLI, using a shutdown checkpoint allows us to have the rule that TLI
    6183             :      * only changes in shutdown checkpoints, which allows some extra error
    6184             :      * checking in xlog_redo.
    6185             :      *
    6186             :      * In promotion, only create a lightweight end-of-recovery record instead
    6187             :      * of a full checkpoint. A checkpoint is requested later, after we're
    6188             :      * fully out of recovery mode and already accepting queries.
    6189             :      */
    6190         366 :     if (ArchiveRecoveryRequested && IsUnderPostmaster &&
    6191          84 :         PromoteIsTriggered())
    6192             :     {
    6193          72 :         promoted = true;
    6194             : 
    6195             :         /*
    6196             :          * Insert a special WAL record to mark the end of recovery, since we
    6197             :          * aren't doing a checkpoint. That means that the checkpointer process
    6198             :          * may likely be in the middle of a time-smoothed restartpoint and
    6199             :          * could continue to be for minutes after this.  That sounds strange,
    6200             :          * but the effect is roughly the same and it would be stranger to try
    6201             :          * to come out of the restartpoint and then checkpoint. We request a
    6202             :          * checkpoint later anyway, just for safety.
    6203             :          */
    6204          72 :         CreateEndOfRecoveryRecord();
    6205             :     }
    6206             :     else
    6207             :     {
    6208         210 :         RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY |
    6209             :                           CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE |
    6210             :                           CHECKPOINT_WAIT);
    6211             :     }
    6212             : 
    6213         282 :     return promoted;
    6214             : }
    6215             : 
    6216             : /*
    6217             :  * Is the system still in recovery?
    6218             :  *
    6219             :  * Unlike testing InRecovery, this works in any process that's connected to
    6220             :  * shared memory.

    6222             : bool
    6223   101991894 : RecoveryInProgress(void)
    6224             : {
    6225             :     /*
    6226             :      * We check shared state each time only until we leave recovery mode. We
    6227             :      * can't re-enter recovery, so there's no need to keep checking after the
    6228             :      * shared variable has once been seen false.
    6229             :      */
    6230   101991894 :     if (!LocalRecoveryInProgress)

    6233             :     {

    6244             :          * We might exit recovery immediately after return, so the caller
    6245             :          * can't rely on 'true' meaning that we're still in recovery anyway.
    6246             :          */

    6251             : 
    6252             : /*

    6269             : 
    6270             : /*
    6271             :  * Is this process allowed to insert new WAL records?
    6272             :  *
    6273             :  * Ordinarily this is essentially equivalent to !RecoveryInProgress().
    6274             :  * But we also have provisions for forcing the result "true" or "false"

    6277             : bool

    6301             : 
    6302             : /*
    6303             :  * Make XLogInsertAllowed() return true in the current process only.
    6304             :  *
    6305             :  * Note: it is allowed to switch LocalXLogInsertAllowed back to -1 later,
    6306             :  * and even call LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed() again after that.

    6310             : static int
    6311        1298 : LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed(void)

    6648             : 
    6649             : /*
    6650             :  * Update the estimate of distance between checkpoints.
    6651             :  *
    6652             :  * The estimate is used to calculate the number of WAL segments to keep
    6653             :  * preallocated, see XLOGfileslop().
    6654             :  */
    6655             : static void
    6656        1476 : UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate(uint64 nbytes)
    6657             : {
    6658             :     /*
    6659             :      * To estimate the number of segments consumed between checkpoints, keep a
    6660             :      * moving average of the amount of WAL generated in previous checkpoint
    6661             :      * cycles. However, if the load is bursty, with quiet periods and busy
    6662             :      * periods, we want to cater for the peak load. So instead of a plain
    6663             :      * moving average, let the average decline slowly if the previous cycle
    6664             :      * used less WAL than estimated, but bump it up immediately if it used
    6665             :      * more.
    6666             :      *
    6667             :      * When checkpoints are triggered by max_wal_size, this should converge to
    6668             :      * CheckpointSegments * wal_segment_size,
    6669             :      *
    6670             :      * Note: This doesn't pay any attention to what caused the checkpoint.
    6671             :      * Checkpoints triggered manually with CHECKPOINT command, or by e.g.
    6672             :      * starting a base backup, are counted the same as those created
    6673             :      * automatically. The slow-decline will largely mask them out, if they are
    6674             :      * not frequent. If they are frequent, it seems reasonable to count them
    6675             :      * in as any others; if you issue a manual checkpoint every 5 minutes and
    6676             :      * never let a timed checkpoint happen, it makes sense to base the
    6677             :      * preallocation on that 5 minute interval rather than whatever
    6678             :      * checkpoint_timeout is set to.
    6679             :      */
    6680        1476 :     PrevCheckPointDistance = nbytes;
    6681        1476 :     if (CheckPointDistanceEstimate < nbytes)
    6682         928 :         CheckPointDistanceEstimate = nbytes;
    6683             :     else
    6684         548 :         CheckPointDistanceEstimate =
    6685         548 :             (0.90 * CheckPointDistanceEstimate + 0.10 * (double) nbytes);
    6686        1476 : }
    6687             : 
    6688             : /*
    6689             :  * Update the ps display for a process running a checkpoint.  Note that
    6690             :  * this routine should not do any allocations so as it can be called
    6691             :  * from a critical section.
    6692             :  */
    6693             : static void
    6694        2952 : update_checkpoint_display(int flags, bool restartpoint, bool reset)
    6695             : {
    6696             :     /*
    6697             :      * The status is reported only for end-of-recovery and shutdown
    6698             :      * checkpoints or shutdown restartpoints.  Updating the ps display is
    6699             :      * useful in those situations as it may not be possible to rely on
    6700             :      * pg_stat_activity to see the status of the checkpointer or the startup
    6701             :      * process.
    6702             :      */
    6703        2952 :     if ((flags & (CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY | CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN)) == 0)
    6704        1264 :         return;
    6705             : 
    6706        1688 :     if (reset)
    6707         844 :         set_ps_display("");
    6708             :     else
    6709             :     {
    6710             :         char        activitymsg[128];
    6711             : 
    6712        2532 :         snprintf(activitymsg, sizeof(activitymsg), "performing %s%s%s",
    6713         844 :                  (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY) ? "end-of-recovery " : "",
    6714         844 :                  (flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN) ? "shutdown " : "",
    6715             :                  restartpoint ? "restartpoint" : "checkpoint");
    6716         844 :         set_ps_display(activitymsg);
    6717             :     }
    6718             : }
    6719             : 
    6720             : 
    6721             : /*
    6722             :  * Perform a checkpoint --- either during shutdown, or on-the-fly
    6723             :  *
    6724             :  * flags is a bitwise OR of the following:
    6725             :  *  CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN: checkpoint is for database shutdown.
    6726             :  *  CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY: checkpoint is for end of WAL recovery.
    6727             :  *  CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE: finish the checkpoint ASAP,
    6728             :  *      ignoring checkpoint_completion_target parameter.
    6729             :  *  CHECKPOINT_FORCE: force a checkpoint even if no XLOG activity has occurred
    6730             :  *      since the last one (implied by CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN or
    6731             :  *      CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY).
    6732             :  *  CHECKPOINT_FLUSH_ALL: also flush buffers of unlogged tables.
    6733             :  *
    6734             :  * Note: flags contains other bits, of interest here only for logging purposes.
    6735             :  * In particular note that this routine is synchronous and does not pay
    6736             :  * attention to CHECKPOINT_WAIT.
    6737             :  *
    6738             :  * If !shutdown then we are writing an online checkpoint. An XLOG_CHECKPOINT_REDO
    6739             :  * record is inserted into WAL at the logical location of the checkpoint, before
    6740             :  * flushing anything to disk, and when the checkpoint is eventually completed,
    6741             :  * and it is from this point that WAL replay will begin in the case of a recovery
    6742             :  * from this checkpoint. Once everything is written to disk, an
    6743             :  * XLOG_CHECKPOINT_ONLINE record is written to complete the checkpoint, and
    6744             :  * points back to the earlier XLOG_CHECKPOINT_REDO record. This mechanism allows
    6745             :  * other write-ahead log records to be written while the checkpoint is in
    6746             :  * progress, but we must be very careful about order of operations. This function
    6747             :  * may take many minutes to execute on a busy system.
    6748             :  *
    6749             :  * On the other hand, when shutdown is true, concurrent insertion into the
    6750             :  * write-ahead log is impossible, so there is no need for two separate records.
    6751             :  * In this case, we only insert an XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN record, and it's
    6752             :  * both the record marking the completion of the checkpoint and the location
    6753             :  * from which WAL replay would begin if needed.
    6754             :  */
    6755             : void
    6756        1410 : CreateCheckPoint(int flags)
    6757             : {
    6758             :     bool        shutdown;
    6759             :     CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    6760             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    6761             :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    6762        1410 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    6763             :     uint32      freespace;
    6764             :     XLogRecPtr  PriorRedoPtr;
    6765             :     XLogRecPtr  last_important_lsn;
    6766             :     VirtualTransactionId *vxids;
    6767             :     int         nvxids;
    6768        1410 :     int         oldXLogAllowed = 0;
    6769             : 
    6770             :     /*
    6771             :      * An end-of-recovery checkpoint is really a shutdown checkpoint, just
    6772             :      * issued at a different time.
    6773             :      */
    6774        1410 :     if (flags & (CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN | CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY))
    6775         818 :         shutdown = true;
    6776             :     else
    6777         592 :         shutdown = false;
    6778             : 
    6779             :     /* sanity check */
    6780        1410 :     if (RecoveryInProgress() && (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY) == 0)

    6918             :      * can be written between the redo point and the insertion of the

    6922        1410 :     if (!shutdown)
    6923             :     {
    6924         592 :         int         dummy = 0;
    6925             :

    6987             : 
    6988             :     /*
    6989             :      * Having constructed the checkpoint record, ensure all shmem disk buffers
    6990             :      * and commit-log buffers are flushed to disk.
    6991             :      *
    6992             :      * This I/O could fail for various reasons.  If so, we will fail to
    6993             :      * complete the checkpoint, but there is no reason to force a system
    6994             :      * panic. Accordingly, exit critical section while doing it.
    6995             :      */
    6996        1410 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    6997             : 
    6998             :     /*
    6999             :      * In some cases there are groups of actions that must all occur on one
    7000             :      * side or the other of a checkpoint record. Before flushing the
    7001             :      * checkpoint record we must explicitly wait for any backend currently
    7002             :      * performing those groups of actions.
    7003             :      *
    7004             :      * One example is end of transaction, so we must wait for any transactions
    7005             :      * that are currently in commit critical sections.  If an xact inserted
    7006             :      * its commit record into XLOG just before the REDO point, then a crash
    7007             :      * restart from the REDO point would not replay that record, which means
    7008             :      * that our flushing had better include the xact's update of pg_xact.  So
    7009             :      * we wait till he's out of his commit critical section before proceeding.
    7010             :      * See notes in RecordTransactionCommit().
    7011             :      *
    7012             :      * Because we've already released the insertion locks, this test is a bit
    7013             :      * fuzzy: it is possible that we will wait for xacts we didn't really need
    7014             :      * to wait for.  But the delay should be short and it seems better to make
    7015             :      * checkpoint take a bit longer than to hold off insertions longer than
    7016             :      * necessary. (In fact, the whole reason we have this issue is that xact.c
    7017             :      * does commit record XLOG insertion and clog update as two separate steps
    7018             :      * protected by different locks, but again that seems best on grounds of
    7019             :      * minimizing lock contention.)
    7020             :      *
    7021             :      * A transaction that has not yet set delayChkptFlags when we look cannot
    7022             :      * be at risk, since it has not inserted its commit record yet; and one
    7023             :      * that's already cleared it is not at risk either, since it's done fixing
    7024             :      * clog and we will correctly flush the update below.  So we cannot miss
    7025             :      * any xacts we need to wait for.
    7026             :      */
    7027        1410 :     vxids = GetVirtualXIDsDelayingChkpt(&nvxids, DELAY_CHKPT_START);
    7028        1410 :     if (nvxids > 0)
    7029             :     {
    7030             :         do
    7031             :         {
    7032          16 :             pgstat_report_wait_start(WAIT_EVENT_CHECKPOINT_DELAY_START);
    7033          16 :             pg_usleep(10000L);  /* wait for 10 msec */
    7034          16 :             pgstat_report_wait_end();
    7035          16 :         } while (HaveVirtualXIDsDelayingChkpt(vxids, nvxids,
    7036             :                                               DELAY_CHKPT_START));

    7038        1410 :     pfree(vxids);

    7040        1410 :     CheckPointGuts(checkPoint.redo, flags);

    7046             :         {

    7078             : 
    7079             :     /*
    7080             :      * We mustn't write any new WAL after a shutdown checkpoint, or it will be
    7081             :      * overwritten at next startup.  No-one should even try, this just allows
    7082             :      * sanity-checking.  In the case of an end-of-recovery checkpoint, we want
    7083             :      * to just temporarily disable writing until the system has exited
    7084             :      * recovery.

    7138             :      * We are now done with critical updates; no need for system panic if we
    7139             :      * have trouble while fooling with old log segments.
    7140             :      */
    7141        1410 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    7142             : 
    7143             :     /*
    7144             :      * WAL summaries end when the next XLOG_CHECKPOINT_REDO or
    7145             :      * XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN record is reached. This is the first point
    7146             :      * where (a) we're not inside of a critical section and (b) we can be
    7147             :      * certain that the relevant record has been flushed to disk, which must
    7148             :      * happen before it can be summarized.
    7149             :      *
    7150             :      * If this is a shutdown checkpoint, then this happens reasonably
    7151             :      * promptly: we've only just inserted and flushed the
    7152             :      * XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN record. If this is not a shutdown checkpoint,
    7153             :      * then this might not be very prompt at all: the XLOG_CHECKPOINT_REDO
    7154             :      * record was written before we began flushing data to disk, and that
    7155             :      * could be many minutes ago at this point. However, we don't XLogFlush()
    7156             :      * after inserting that record, so we're not guaranteed that it's on disk
    7157             :      * until after the above call that flushes the XLOG_CHECKPOINT_ONLINE
    7158             :      * record.
    7159             :      */
    7160        1410 :     SetWalSummarizerLatch();
    7161             : 
    7162             :     /*
    7163             :      * Let smgr do post-checkpoint cleanup (eg, deleting old files).
    7164             :      */

    7201             : 
    7202             :     /*
    7203             :      * Truncate pg_subtrans if possible.  We can throw away all data before
    7204             :      * the oldest XMIN of any running transaction.  No future transaction will
    7205             :      * attempt to reference any pg_subtrans entry older than that (see Asserts
    7206             :      * in subtrans.c).  During recovery, though, we mustn't do this because
    7207             :      * StartupSUBTRANS hasn't been called yet.
    7208             :      */
    7209        1410 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    7210        1356 :         TruncateSUBTRANS(GetOldestTransactionIdConsideredRunning());
    7211             : 
    7212             :     /* Real work is done; log and update stats. */
    7213        1410 :     LogCheckpointEnd(false);
    7214             : 
    7215             :     /* Reset the process title */
    7216        1410 :     update_checkpoint_display(flags, false, true);
    7217             : 
    7218        1410 :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_CHECKPOINT_DONE(CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written,
    7219             :                                      NBuffers,
    7220             :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_added,
    7221             :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed,
    7222             :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled);
    7223             : }
    7224             : 
    7225             : /*
    7226             :  * Mark the end of recovery in WAL though without running a full checkpoint.
    7227             :  * We can expect that a restartpoint is likely to be in progress as we
    7228             :  * do this, though we are unwilling to wait for it to complete.
    7229             :  *
    7230             :  * CreateRestartPoint() allows for the case where recovery may end before
    7231             :  * the restartpoint completes so there is no concern of concurrent behaviour.
    7232             :  */
    7233             : static void
    7234          72 : CreateEndOfRecoveryRecord(void)
    7235             : {
    7236             :     xl_end_of_recovery xlrec;
    7237             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    7238             : 
    7239             :     /* sanity check */
    7240          72 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    7241           0 :         elog(ERROR, "can only be used to end recovery");
    7242             : 
    7243          72 :     xlrec.end_time = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    7244             : 
    7245          72 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    7246          72 :     xlrec.ThisTimeLineID = XLogCtl->InsertTimeLineID;
    7247          72 :     xlrec.PrevTimeLineID = XLogCtl->PrevTimeLineID;
    7248          72 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    7249             : 
    7250          72 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    7251             : 
    7252          72 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    7253          72 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xl_end_of_recovery));
    7254          72 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_END_OF_RECOVERY);
    7255             : 
    7256          72 :     XLogFlush(recptr);
    7257             : 
    7258             :     /*
    7259             :      * Update the control file so that crash recovery can follow the timeline
    7260             :      * changes to this point.
    7261             :      */
    7262          72 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    7263          72 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint = recptr;
    7264          72 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI = xlrec.ThisTimeLineID;
    7265          72 :     UpdateControlFile();
    7266          72 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    7267             : 
    7268          72 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    7269          72 : }
    7270             : 
    7271             : /*
    7272             :  * Write an OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD message.
    7273             :  *
    7274             :  * When on WAL replay we expect a continuation record at the start of a page
    7275             :  * that is not there, recovery ends and WAL writing resumes at that point.
    7276             :  * But it's wrong to resume writing new WAL back at the start of the record
    7277             :  * that was broken, because downstream consumers of that WAL (physical
    7278             :  * replicas) are not prepared to "rewind".  So the first action after
    7279             :  * finishing replay of all valid WAL must be to write a record of this type
    7280             :  * at the point where the contrecord was missing; to support xlogreader
    7281             :  * detecting the special case, XLP_FIRST_IS_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD is also added
    7282             :  * to the page header where the record occurs.  xlogreader has an ad-hoc
    7283             :  * mechanism to report metadata about the broken record, which is what we
    7284             :  * use here.
    7285             :  *
    7286             :  * At replay time, XLP_FIRST_IS_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD instructs xlogreader to
    7287             :  * skip the record it was reading, and pass back the LSN of the skipped
    7288             :  * record, so that its caller can verify (on "replay" of that record) that the
    7289             :  * XLOG_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD matches what was effectively overwritten.
    7290             :  *
    7291             :  * 'aborted_lsn' is the beginning position of the record that was incomplete.
    7292             :  * It is included in the WAL record.  'pagePtr' and 'newTLI' point to the
    7293             :  * beginning of the XLOG page where the record is to be inserted.  They must
    7294             :  * match the current WAL insert position, they're passed here just so that we
    7295             :  * can verify that.
    7296             :  */
    7297             : static XLogRecPtr
    7298          20 : CreateOverwriteContrecordRecord(XLogRecPtr aborted_lsn, XLogRecPtr pagePtr,
    7299             :                                 TimeLineID newTLI)
    7300             : {
    7301             :     xl_overwrite_contrecord xlrec;
    7302             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    7303             :     XLogPageHeader pagehdr;
    7304             :     XLogRecPtr  startPos;
    7305             : 
    7306             :     /* sanity checks */
    7307          20 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    7308           0 :         elog(ERROR, "can only be used at end of recovery");
    7309          20 :     if (pagePtr % XLOG_BLCKSZ != 0)
    7310           0 :         elog(ERROR, "invalid position for missing continuation record %X/%X",
    7311             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(pagePtr));
    7312             : 
    7313             :     /* The current WAL insert position should be right after the page header */
    7314          20 :     startPos = pagePtr;
    7315          20 :     if (XLogSegmentOffset(startPos, wal_segment_size) == 0)
    7316           2 :         startPos += SizeOfXLogLongPHD;
    7317             :     else
    7318          18 :         startPos += SizeOfXLogShortPHD;
    7319          20 :     recptr = GetXLogInsertRecPtr();
    7320          20 :     if (recptr != startPos)
    7321           0 :         elog(ERROR, "invalid WAL insert position %X/%X for OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD",
    7322             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(recptr));
    7323             : 
    7324          20 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    7325             : 
    7326             :     /*
    7327             :      * Initialize the XLOG page header (by GetXLogBuffer), and set the
    7328             :      * XLP_FIRST_IS_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD flag.
    7329             :      *
    7330             :      * No other backend is allowed to write WAL yet, so acquiring the WAL
    7331             :      * insertion lock is just pro forma.
    7332             :      */
    7333          20 :     WALInsertLockAcquire();
    7334          20 :     pagehdr = (XLogPageHeader) GetXLogBuffer(pagePtr, newTLI);
    7335          20 :     pagehdr->xlp_info |= XLP_FIRST_IS_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD;
    7336          20 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    7337             : 
    7338             :     /*
    7339             :      * Insert the XLOG_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD record as the first record on the
    7340             :      * page.  We know it becomes the first record, because no other backend is
    7341             :      * allowed to write WAL yet.
    7342             :      */
    7343          20 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    7344          20 :     xlrec.overwritten_lsn = aborted_lsn;
    7345          20 :     xlrec.overwrite_time = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    7346          20 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xl_overwrite_contrecord));
    7347          20 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD);
    7348             : 
    7349             :     /* check that the record was inserted to the right place */
    7350          20 :     if (ProcLastRecPtr != startPos)
    7351           0 :         elog(ERROR, "OVERWRITE_CONTRECORD was inserted to unexpected position %X/%X",
    7352             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(ProcLastRecPtr));
    7353             : 
    7354          20 :     XLogFlush(recptr);
    7355             : 
    7356          20 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    7357             : 
    7358          20 :     return recptr;
    7359             : }
    7360             : 
    7361             : /*
    7362             :  * Flush all data in shared memory to disk, and fsync
    7363             :  *
    7364             :  * This is the common code shared between regular checkpoints and
    7365             :  * recovery restartpoints.
    7366             :  */
    7367             : static void
    7368        1476 : CheckPointGuts(XLogRecPtr checkPointRedo, int flags)
    7369             : {
    7370        1476 :     CheckPointRelationMap();
    7371        1476 :     CheckPointReplicationSlots(flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN);
    7372        1476 :     CheckPointSnapBuild();
    7373        1476 :     CheckPointLogicalRewriteHeap();
    7374        1476 :     CheckPointReplicationOrigin();
    7375             : 
    7376             :     /* Write out all dirty data in SLRUs and the main buffer pool */
    7377        1476 :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_BUFFER_CHECKPOINT_START(flags);
    7378        1476 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_write_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    7379        1476 :     CheckPointCLOG();
    7380        1476 :     CheckPointCommitTs();
    7381        1476 :     CheckPointSUBTRANS();
    7382        1476 :     CheckPointMultiXact();
    7383        1476 :     CheckPointPredicate();
    7384        1476 :     CheckPointBuffers(flags);
    7385             : 
    7386             :     /* Perform all queued up fsyncs */
    7387        1476 :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_BUFFER_CHECKPOINT_SYNC_START();
    7388        1476 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    7389        1476 :     ProcessSyncRequests();
    7390        1476 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_end_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    7391        1476 :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_BUFFER_CHECKPOINT_DONE();
    7392             : 
    7393             :     /* We deliberately delay 2PC checkpointing as long as possible */
    7394        1476 :     CheckPointTwoPhase(checkPointRedo);
    7395        1476 : }
    7396             : 
    7397             : /*
    7398             :  * Save a checkpoint for recovery restart if appropriate
    7399             :  *
    7400             :  * This function is called each time a checkpoint record is read from XLOG.
    7401             :  * It must determine whether the checkpoint represents a safe restartpoint or
    7402             :  * not.  If so, the checkpoint record is stashed in shared memory so that
    7403             :  * CreateRestartPoint can consult it.  (Note that the latter function is
    7404             :  * executed by the checkpointer, while this one will be executed by the
    7405             :  * startup process.)
    7406             :  */
    7407             : static void
    7408         368 : RecoveryRestartPoint(const CheckPoint *checkPoint, XLogReaderState *record)
    7409             : {
    7410             :     /*
    7411             :      * Also refrain from creating a restartpoint if we have seen any
    7412             :      * references to non-existent pages. Restarting recovery from the
    7413             :      * restartpoint would not see the references, so we would lose the
    7414             :      * cross-check that the pages belonged to a relation that was dropped
    7415             :      * later.
    7416             :      */
    7417         368 :     if (XLogHaveInvalidPages())
    7418             :     {
    7419           0 :         elog(DEBUG2,
    7420             :              "could not record restart point at %X/%X because there "
    7421             :              "are unresolved references to invalid pages",
    7422             :              LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(checkPoint->redo));
    7423           0 :         return;
    7424             :     }
    7425             : 
    7426             :     /*
    7427             :      * Copy the checkpoint record to shared memory, so that checkpointer can
    7428             :      * work out the next time it wants to perform a restartpoint.
    7429             :      */
    7430         368 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    7431         368 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPointRecPtr = record->ReadRecPtr;
    7432         368 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPointEndPtr = record->EndRecPtr;
    7433         368 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPoint = *checkPoint;
    7434         368 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    7435             : }
    7436             : 
    7437             : /*
    7438             :  * Establish a restartpoint if possible.
    7439             :  *
    7440             :  * This is similar to CreateCheckPoint, but is used during WAL recovery
    7441             :  * to establish a point from which recovery can roll forward without
    7442             :  * replaying the entire recovery log.
    7443             :  *
    7444             :  * Returns true if a new restartpoint was established. We can only establish
    7445             :  * a restartpoint if we have replayed a safe checkpoint record since last
    7446             :  * restartpoint.
    7447             :  */

    7449         134 : CreateRestartPoint(int flags)

    7460             :     TimestampTz xtime;
    7461             : 
    7462             :     /* Concurrent checkpoint/restartpoint cannot happen */
    7463         134 :     Assert(!IsUnderPostmaster || MyBackendType == B_CHECKPOINTER);
    7464             : 
    7465             :     /* Get a local copy of the last safe checkpoint record. */
    7466         134 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    7467         134 :     lastCheckPointRecPtr = XLogCtl->lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    7468         134 :     lastCheckPointEndPtr = XLogCtl->lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    7469         134 :     lastCheckPoint = XLogCtl->lastCheckPoint;
    7470         134 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    7471             : 
    7472             :     /*
    7473             :      * Check that we're still in recovery mode. It's ok if we exit recovery
    7474             :      * mode after this check, the restart point is valid anyway.
    7475             :      */
    7476         134 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    7477             :     {
    7478           0 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    7479             :                 (errmsg_internal("skipping restartpoint, recovery has already ended")));
    7480           0 :         return false;
    7481             :     }
    7482             : 
    7483             :     /*
    7484             :      * If the last checkpoint record we've replayed is already our last
    7485             :      * restartpoint, we can't perform a new restart point. We still update
    7486             :      * minRecoveryPoint in that case, so that if this is a shutdown restart
    7487             :      * point, we won't start up earlier than before. That's not strictly
    7488             :      * necessary, but when hot standby is enabled, it would be rather weird if
    7489             :      * the database opened up for read-only connections at a point-in-time
    7490             :      * before the last shutdown. Such time travel is still possible in case of
    7491             :      * immediate shutdown, though.
    7492             :      *
    7493             :      * We don't explicitly advance minRecoveryPoint when we do create a
    7494             :      * restartpoint. It's assumed that flushing the buffers will do that as a
    7495             :      * side-effect.
    7496             :      */
    7497         134 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(lastCheckPointRecPtr) ||
    7498         132 :         lastCheckPoint.redo <= ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo)
    7499             :     {
    7500          68 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    7501             :                 (errmsg_internal("skipping restartpoint, already performed at %X/%X",
    7502             :                                  LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(lastCheckPoint.redo))));
    7503             : 
    7504          68 :         UpdateMinRecoveryPoint(InvalidXLogRecPtr, true);
    7505          68 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN)
    7506             :         {
    7507          36 :             LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    7508          36 :             ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY;

    7512          68 :         return false;
    7513             :     }
    7514             : 
    7515             :     /*

    7518             :      * restartpoint if it exceeds CheckPointSegments.
    7519             :      *

    7521             :      * during recovery this is just pro forma, because no WAL insertions are
    7522             :      * happening.

    7574             :         /*
    7575             :          * Ensure minRecoveryPoint is past the checkpoint record and update it

    7577             :          * this will have happened already while writing out dirty buffers,
    7578             :          * but not necessarily - e.g. because no buffers were dirtied.  We do
    7579             :          * this because a backup performed in recovery uses minRecoveryPoint
    7580             :          * to determine which WAL files must be included in the backup, and
    7581             :          * the file (or files) containing the checkpoint record must be
    7582             :          * included, at a minimum.  Note that for an ordinary restart of
    7583             :          * recovery there's no value in having the minimum recovery point any
    7584             :          * earlier than this anyway, because redo will begin just after the

    7636             :     }
    7637          66 :     _logSegNo--;
    7638             : 
    7639             :     /*
    7640             :      * Try to recycle segments on a useful timeline. If we've been promoted
    7641             :      * since the beginning of this restartpoint, use the new timeline chosen
    7642             :      * at end of recovery.  If we're still in recovery, use the timeline we're
    7643             :      * currently replaying.
    7644             :      *
    7645             :      * There is no guarantee that the WAL segments will be useful on the
    7646             :      * current timeline; if recovery proceeds to a new timeline right after
    7647             :      * this, the pre-allocated WAL segments on this timeline will not be used,
    7648             :      * and will go wasted until recycled on the next restartpoint. We'll live
    7649             :      * with that.
    7650             :      */
    7651          66 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    7652           0 :         replayTLI = XLogCtl->InsertTimeLineID;
    7653             : 
    7654          66 :     RemoveOldXlogFiles(_logSegNo, RedoRecPtr, endptr, replayTLI);
    7655             : 
    7656             :     /*
    7657             :      * Make more log segments if needed.  (Do this after recycling old log
    7658             :      * segments, since that may supply some of the needed files.)
    7659             :      */
    7660          66 :     PreallocXlogFiles(endptr, replayTLI);
    7661             : 
    7662             :     /*
    7663             :      * Truncate pg_subtrans if possible.  We can throw away all data before
    7664             :      * the oldest XMIN of any running transaction.  No future transaction will
    7665             :      * attempt to reference any pg_subtrans entry older than that (see Asserts
    7666             :      * in subtrans.c).  When hot standby is disabled, though, we mustn't do
    7667             :      * this because StartupSUBTRANS hasn't been called yet.
    7668             :      */

    7673          66 :     LogCheckpointEnd(true);
    7674             :

    7676          66 :     update_checkpoint_display(flags, true, true);
    7677             : 
    7678          66 :     xtime = GetLatestXTime();

    7681             :                     LSN_FORMAT_ARGS(lastCheckPoint.redo)),

    7683             :                                timestamptz_to_str(xtime)) : 0));

    7685             :     /*

    7695             : }
    7696             : 
    7697             : /*
    7698             :  * Report availability of WAL for the given target LSN
    7699             :  *      (typically a slot's restart_lsn)
    7700             :  *
    7701             :  * Returns one of the following enum values:
    7702             :  *
    7703             :  * * WALAVAIL_RESERVED means targetLSN is available and it is in the range of
    7704             :  *   max_wal_size.
    7705             :  *
    7706             :  * * WALAVAIL_EXTENDED means it is still available by preserving extra
    7707             :  *   segments beyond max_wal_size. If max_slot_wal_keep_size is smaller
    7708             :  *   than max_wal_size, this state is not returned.
    7709             :  *
    7710             :  * * WALAVAIL_UNRESERVED means it is being lost and the next checkpoint will
    7711             :  *   remove reserved segments. The walsender using this slot may return to the
    7712             :  *   above.
    7713             :  *
    7714             :  * * WALAVAIL_REMOVED means it has been removed. A replication stream on
    7715             :  *   a slot with this LSN cannot continue.  (Any associated walsender
    7716             :  *   processes should have been terminated already.)
    7717             :  *
    7718             :  * * WALAVAIL_INVALID_LSN means the slot hasn't been set to reserve WAL.
    7719             :  */
    7720             : WALAvailability
    7721         570 : GetWALAvailability(XLogRecPtr targetLSN)
    7722             : {
    7723             :     XLogRecPtr  currpos;        /* current write LSN */
    7724             :     XLogSegNo   currSeg;        /* segid of currpos */
    7725             :     XLogSegNo   targetSeg;      /* segid of targetLSN */
    7726             :     XLogSegNo   oldestSeg;      /* actual oldest segid */
    7727             :     XLogSegNo   oldestSegMaxWalSize;    /* oldest segid kept by max_wal_size */
    7728             :     XLogSegNo   oldestSlotSeg;  /* oldest segid kept by slot */
    7729             :     uint64      keepSegs;
    7730             : 
    7731             :     /*
    7732             :      * slot does not reserve WAL. Either deactivated, or has never been active
    7733             :      */
    7734         570 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(targetLSN))
    7735          12 :         return WALAVAIL_INVALID_LSN;
    7736             : 
    7737             :     /*
    7738             :      * Calculate the oldest segment currently reserved by all slots,
    7739             :      * considering wal_keep_size and max_slot_wal_keep_size.  Initialize
    7740             :      * oldestSlotSeg to the current segment.
    7741             :      */
    7742         558 :     currpos = GetXLogWriteRecPtr();
    7743         558 :     XLByteToSeg(currpos, oldestSlotSeg, wal_segment_size);
    7744         558 :     KeepLogSeg(currpos, &oldestSlotSeg);
    7745             : 
    7746             :     /*
    7747             :      * Find the oldest extant segment file. We get 1 until checkpoint removes
    7748             :      * the first WAL segment file since startup, which causes the status being
    7749             :      * wrong under certain abnormal conditions but that doesn't actually harm.
    7750             :      */

    7752             :

    7758          16 :         oldestSegMaxWalSize = currSeg - keepSegs;

    7760         542 :         oldestSegMaxWalSize = 1;
    7761             : 
    7762             :     /* the segment we care about */
    7763         558 :     XLByteToSeg(targetLSN, targetSeg, wal_segment_size);
    7764             : 
    7765             :     /*
    7766             :      * No point in returning reserved or extended status values if the

    7770             :     {
    7771             :         /* show "reserved" when targetSeg is within max_wal_size */

    7774             :

    7778             :

    7782             : 
    7783             :     /* Definitely lost */
    7784           0 :     return WALAVAIL_REMOVED;
    7785             : }
    7786             : 
    7787             : 
    7788             : /*
    7789             :  * Retreat *logSegNo to the last segment that we need to retain because of
    7790             :  * either wal_keep_size or replication slots.
    7791             :  *
    7792             :  * This is calculated by subtracting wal_keep_size from the given xlog
    7793             :  * location, recptr and by making sure that that result is below the
    7794             :  * requirement of replication slots.  For the latter criterion we do consider
    7795             :  * the effects of max_slot_wal_keep_size: reserve at most that much space back
    7796             :  * from recptr.
    7797             :  *
    7798             :  * Note about replication slots: if this function calculates a value
    7799             :  * that's further ahead than what slots need reserved, then affected
    7800             :  * slots need to be invalidated and this function invoked again.
    7801             :  * XXX it might be a good idea to rewrite this function so that
    7802             :  * invalidation is optionally done here, instead.
    7803             :  */
    7804             : static void
    7805        2040 : KeepLogSeg(XLogRecPtr recptr, XLogSegNo *logSegNo)
    7806             : {
    7807             :     XLogSegNo   currSegNo;
    7808             :     XLogSegNo   segno;
    7809             :     XLogRecPtr  keep;
    7810             : 
    7811        2040 :     XLByteToSeg(recptr, currSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    7812        2040 :     segno = currSegNo;
    7813             : 
    7814             :     /*
    7815             :      * Calculate how many segments are kept by slots first, adjusting for
    7816             :      * max_slot_wal_keep_size.
    7817             :      */
    7818        2040 :     keep = XLogGetReplicationSlotMinimumLSN();
    7819        2040 :     if (keep != InvalidXLogRecPtr && keep < recptr)
    7820             :     {
    7821         490 :         XLByteToSeg(keep, segno, wal_segment_size);
    7822             :

    7829          38 :                 ConvertToXSegs(max_slot_wal_keep_size_mb, wal_segment_size);

    7870             : 
    7871             : /*
    7872             :  * Write a NEXTOID log record
    7873             :  */
    7874             : void
    7875         902 : XLogPutNextOid(Oid nextOid)
    7876             : {
    7877         902 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    7878         902 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) (&nextOid), sizeof(Oid));
    7879         902 :     (void) XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_NEXTOID);
    7880             : 
    7881             :     /*
    7882             :      * We need not flush the NEXTOID record immediately, because any of the
    7883             :      * just-allocated OIDs could only reach disk as part of a tuple insert or
    7884             :      * update that would have its own XLOG record that must follow the NEXTOID
    7885             :      * record.  Therefore, the standard buffer LSN interlock applied to those
    7886             :      * records will ensure no such OID reaches disk before the NEXTOID record
    7887             :      * does.
    7888             :      *
    7889             :      * Note, however, that the above statement only covers state "within" the
    7890             :      * database.  When we use a generated OID as a file or directory name, we
    7891             :      * are in a sense violating the basic WAL rule, because that filesystem
    7892             :      * change may reach disk before the NEXTOID WAL record does.  The impact
    7893             :      * of this is that if a database crash occurs immediately afterward, we
    7894             :      * might after restart re-generate the same OID and find that it conflicts
    7895             :      * with the leftover file or directory.  But since for safety's sake we
    7896             :      * always loop until finding a nonconflicting filename, this poses no real
    7897             :      * problem in practice. See pgsql-hackers discussion 27-Sep-2006.
    7898             :      */
    7899         902 : }
    7900             : 
    7901             : /*
    7902             :  * Write an XLOG SWITCH record.
    7903             :  *
    7904             :  * Here we just blindly issue an XLogInsert request for the record.
    7905             :  * All the magic happens inside XLogInsert.
    7906             :  *
    7907             :  * The return value is either the end+1 address of the switch record,
    7908             :  * or the end+1 address of the prior segment if we did not need to
    7909             :  * write a switch record because we are already at segment start.
    7910             :  */
    7911             : XLogRecPtr
    7912         624 : RequestXLogSwitch(bool mark_unimportant)
    7913             : {
    7914             :     XLogRecPtr  RecPtr;
    7915             : 
    7916             :     /* XLOG SWITCH has no data */
    7917         624 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    7918             : 
    7919         624 :     if (mark_unimportant)
    7920           0 :         XLogSetRecordFlags(XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT);
    7921         624 :     RecPtr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_SWITCH);
    7922             : 
    7923         624 :     return RecPtr;
    7924             : }

    8010             : /*

    8220         318 :         LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);

    8226             :         /*
    8227             :          * We ignore the nextOid counter in an ONLINE checkpoint, preferring
    8228             :          * to track OID assignment through XLOG_NEXTOID records.  The nextOid
    8229             :          * counter is from the start of the checkpoint and might well be stale
    8230             :          * compared to later XLOG_NEXTOID records.  We could try to take the
    8231             :          * maximum of the nextOid counter and our latest value, but since
    8232             :          * there's no particular guarantee about the speed with which the OID
    8233             :          * counter wraps around, that's a risky thing to do.  In any case,
    8234             :          * users of the nextOid counter are required to avoid assignment of
    8235             :          * duplicates, so that a somewhat out-of-date value should be safe.
    8236             :          */
