    8611             : 
    8612             : /*
    8613             :  * do_pg_backup_start is the workhorse of the user-visible pg_backup_start()
    8614             :  * function. It creates the necessary starting checkpoint and constructs the
    8615             :  * backup state and tablespace map.
    8616             :  *
    8617             :  * Input parameters are "state" (the backup state), "fast" (if true, we do
    8618             :  * the checkpoint in immediate mode to make it faster), and "tablespaces"
    8619             :  * (if non-NULL, indicates a list of tablespaceinfo structs describing the
    8620             :  * cluster's tablespaces.).
    8621             :  *
    8622             :  * The tablespace map contents are appended to passed-in parameter
    8623             :  * tablespace_map and the caller is responsible for including it in the backup
    8624             :  * archive as 'tablespace_map'. The tablespace_map file is required mainly for
    8625             :  * tar format in windows as native windows utilities are not able to create
    8626             :  * symlinks while extracting files from tar. However for consistency and
    8627             :  * platform-independence, we do it the same way everywhere.
    8628             :  *
    8629             :  * It fills in "state" with the information required for the backup, such
    8630             :  * as the minimum WAL location that must be present to restore from this
    8631             :  * backup (starttli) and the corresponding timeline ID (starttli).
    8632             :  *
    8633             :  * Every successfully started backup must be stopped by calling
    8634             :  * do_pg_backup_stop() or do_pg_abort_backup(). There can be many
    8635             :  * backups active at the same time.
    8636             :  *
    8637             :  * It is the responsibility of the caller of this function to verify the
    8638             :  * permissions of the calling user!
    8639             :  */
    8640             : void
    8641         268 : do_pg_backup_start(const char *backupidstr, bool fast, List **tablespaces,
    8642             :                    BackupState *state, StringInfo tblspcmapfile)
    8643             : {
    8644             :     bool        backup_started_in_recovery;
    8645             : 
    8646         268 :     Assert(state != NULL);
    8647         268 :     backup_started_in_recovery = RecoveryInProgress();
    8648             : 
    8649             :     /*
    8650             :      * During recovery, we don't need to check WAL level. Because, if WAL
    8651             :      * level is not sufficient, it's impossible to get here during recovery.
    8652             :      */
    8653         268 :     if (!backup_started_in_recovery && !XLogIsNeeded())
    8654           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    8655             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
    8656             :                  errmsg("WAL level not sufficient for making an online backup"),
    8657             :                  errhint("wal_level must be set to \"replica\" or \"logical\" at server start.")));
    8658             : 
    8659         268 :     if (strlen(backupidstr) > MAXPGPATH)
    8660           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
    8661             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE),
    8662             :                  errmsg("backup label too long (max %d bytes)",
    8663             :                         MAXPGPATH)));
    8664             : 
    8665         266 :     memcpy(state->name, backupidstr, strlen(backupidstr));
    8666             : 
    8667             :     /*
    8668             :      * Mark backup active in shared memory.  We must do full-page WAL writes
    8669             :      * during an on-line backup even if not doing so at other times, because
    8670             :      * it's quite possible for the backup dump to obtain a "torn" (partially
    8671             :      * written) copy of a database page if it reads the page concurrently with
    8672             :      * our write to the same page.  This can be fixed as long as the first
    8673             :      * write to the page in the WAL sequence is a full-page write. Hence, we
    8674             :      * increment runningBackups then force a CHECKPOINT, to ensure there are
    8675             :      * no dirty pages in shared memory that might get dumped while the backup
    8676             :      * is in progress without having a corresponding WAL record.  (Once the
    8677             :      * backup is complete, we need not force full-page writes anymore, since
    8678             :      * we expect that any pages not modified during the backup interval must
    8679             :      * have been correctly captured by the backup.)
    8680             :      *
    8681             :      * Note that forcing full-page writes has no effect during an online
    8682             :      * backup from the standby.
    8683             :      *
    8684             :      * We must hold all the insertion locks to change the value of
    8685             :      * runningBackups, to ensure adequate interlocking against
    8686             :      * XLogInsertRecord().
    8687             :      */
    8688         266 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    8689         266 :     XLogCtl->Insert.runningBackups++;
    8690         266 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    8691             : 
    8692             :     /*
    8693             :      * Ensure we decrement runningBackups if we fail below. NB -- for this to
    8694             :      * work correctly, it is critical that sessionBackupState is only updated
    8695             :      * after this block is over.
    8696             :      */
    8697         266 :     PG_ENSURE_ERROR_CLEANUP(do_pg_abort_backup, DatumGetBool(true));
    8698             :     {
    8699         266 :         bool        gotUniqueStartpoint = false;
    8700             :         DIR        *tblspcdir;
    8701             :         struct dirent *de;
    8702             :         tablespaceinfo *ti;
    8703             :         int         datadirpathlen;
    8704             : 
    8705             :         /*
    8706             :          * Force an XLOG file switch before the checkpoint, to ensure that the
    8707             :          * WAL segment the checkpoint is written to doesn't contain pages with
    8708             :          * old timeline IDs.  That would otherwise happen if you called
    8709             :          * pg_backup_start() right after restoring from a PITR archive: the
    8710             :          * first WAL segment containing the startup checkpoint has pages in
    8711             :          * the beginning with the old timeline ID.  That can cause trouble at
    8712             :          * recovery: we won't have a history file covering the old timeline if
    8713             :          * pg_wal directory was not included in the base backup and the WAL
    8714             :          * archive was cleared too before starting the backup.
    8715             :          *
    8716             :          * This also ensures that we have emitted a WAL page header that has
    8717             :          * XLP_BKP_REMOVABLE off before we emit the checkpoint record.
    8718             :          * Therefore, if a WAL archiver (such as pglesslog) is trying to
    8719             :          * compress out removable backup blocks, it won't remove any that
    8720             :          * occur after this point.
    8721             :          *
    8722             :          * During recovery, we skip forcing XLOG file switch, which means that
    8723             :          * the backup taken during recovery is not available for the special
    8724             :          * recovery case described above.
    8725             :          */
    8726         266 :         if (!backup_started_in_recovery)
    8727         256 :             RequestXLogSwitch(false);
    8728             : 
    8729             :         do
    8730             :         {
    8731             :             bool        checkpointfpw;
    8732             : 
    8733             :             /*
    8734             :              * Force a CHECKPOINT.  Aside from being necessary to prevent torn
    8735             :              * page problems, this guarantees that two successive backup runs
    8736             :              * will have different checkpoint positions and hence different
    8737             :              * history file names, even if nothing happened in between.
    8738             :              *
    8739             :              * During recovery, establish a restartpoint if possible. We use
    8740             :              * the last restartpoint as the backup starting checkpoint. This
    8741             :              * means that two successive backup runs can have same checkpoint
    8742             :              * positions.
    8743             :              *
    8744             :              * Since the fact that we are executing do_pg_backup_start()
    8745             :              * during recovery means that checkpointer is running, we can use
    8746             :              * RequestCheckpoint() to establish a restartpoint.
    8747             :              *
    8748             :              * We use CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE only if requested by user (via
    8749             :              * passing fast = true).  Otherwise this can take awhile.
    8750             :              */
    8751         266 :             RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_FORCE | CHECKPOINT_WAIT |
    8752             :                               (fast ? CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE : 0));
    8753             : 
    8754             :             /*
    8755             :              * Now we need to fetch the checkpoint record location, and also
    8756             :              * its REDO pointer.  The oldest point in WAL that would be needed
    8757             :              * to restore starting from the checkpoint is precisely the REDO
    8758             :              * pointer.
    8759             :              */
    8760         266 :             LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_SHARED);
    8761         266 :             state->checkpointloc = ControlFile->checkPoint;
    8762         266 :             state->startpoint = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo;
    8763         266 :             state->starttli = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.ThisTimeLineID;
    8764         266 :             checkpointfpw = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.fullPageWrites;
    8765         266 :             LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    8766             : 
    8767         266 :             if (backup_started_in_recovery)
    8768             :             {
    8769             :                 XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8770             : 
    8771             :                 /*
    8772             :                  * Check to see if all WAL replayed during online backup
    8773             :                  * (i.e., since last restartpoint used as backup starting
    8774             :                  * checkpoint) contain full-page writes.
    8775             :                  */
    8776          10 :                 SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8777          10 :                 recptr = XLogCtl->lastFpwDisableRecPtr;
    8778          10 :                 SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8779             : 
    8780          10 :                 if (!checkpointfpw || state->startpoint <= recptr)
    8781           0 :                     ereport(ERROR,
    8782             :                             (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
    8783             :                              errmsg("WAL generated with full_page_writes=off was replayed "
    8784             :                                     "since last restartpoint"),
    8785             :                              errhint("This means that the backup being taken on the standby "
    8786             :                                      "is corrupt and should not be used. "
    8787             :                                      "Enable full_page_writes and run CHECKPOINT on the primary, "
    8788             :                                      "and then try an online backup again.")));
    8789             : 
    8790             :                 /*
    8791             :                  * During recovery, since we don't use the end-of-backup WAL
    8792             :                  * record and don't write the backup history file, the
    8793             :                  * starting WAL location doesn't need to be unique. This means
    8794             :                  * that two base backups started at the same time might use
    8795             :                  * the same checkpoint as starting locations.
    8796             :                  */
    8797          10 :                 gotUniqueStartpoint = true;
    8798             :             }
    8799             : 
    8800             :             /*
    8801             :              * If two base backups are started at the same time (in WAL sender
    8802             :              * processes), we need to make sure that they use different
    8803             :              * checkpoints as starting locations, because we use the starting
    8804             :              * WAL location as a unique identifier for the base backup in the
    8805             :              * end-of-backup WAL record and when we write the backup history
    8806             :              * file. Perhaps it would be better generate a separate unique ID
    8807             :              * for each backup instead of forcing another checkpoint, but
    8808             :              * taking a checkpoint right after another is not that expensive
    8809             :              * either because only few buffers have been dirtied yet.
    8810             :              */
    8811         266 :             WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    8812         266 :             if (XLogCtl->Insert.lastBackupStart < state->startpoint)
    8813             :             {
    8814         266 :                 XLogCtl->Insert.lastBackupStart = state->startpoint;
    8815         266 :                 gotUniqueStartpoint = true;
    8816             :             }
    8817         266 :             WALInsertLockRelease();

    8954             : 
    8955             : /*
    8956             :  * do_pg_backup_stop
    8957             :  *
    8958             :  * Utility function called at the end of an online backup.  It creates history
    8959             :  * file (if required), resets sessionBackupState and so on.  It can optionally
    8960             :  * wait for WAL segments to be archived.
    8961             :  *
    8962             :  * "state" is filled with the information necessary to restore from this
    8963             :  * backup with its stop LSN (stoppoint), its timeline ID (stoptli), etc.
    8964             :  *
    8965             :  * It is the responsibility of the caller of this function to verify the
    8966             :  * permissions of the calling user!
    8967             :  */
    8968             : void
    8969         252 : do_pg_backup_stop(BackupState *state, bool waitforarchive)
    8970             : {
    8971         252 :     bool        backup_stopped_in_recovery = false;
    8972             :     char        histfilepath[MAXPGPATH];
    8973             :     char        lastxlogfilename[MAXFNAMELEN];
    8974             :     char        histfilename[MAXFNAMELEN];
    8975             :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    8976             :     FILE       *fp;
    8977             :     int         seconds_before_warning;
    8978         252 :     int         waits = 0;
    8979         252 :     bool        reported_waiting = false;
    8980             : 
    8981         252 :     Assert(state != NULL);
    8982             : 
    8983         252 :     backup_stopped_in_recovery = RecoveryInProgress();
    8984             : 
    8985             :     /*
    8986             :      * During recovery, we don't need to check WAL level. Because, if WAL
    8987             :      * level is not sufficient, it's impossible to get here during recovery.
    8988             :      */
    8989         252 :     if (!backup_stopped_in_recovery && !XLogIsNeeded())
    8990           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    8991             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
    8992             :                  errmsg("WAL level not sufficient for making an online backup"),
    8993             :                  errhint("wal_level must be set to \"replica\" or \"logical\" at server start.")));
    8994             : 
    8995             :     /*
    8996             :      * OK to update backup counter and session-level lock.
    8997             :      *
    8998             :      * Note that CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS() must not occur while updating them,
    8999             :      * otherwise they can be updated inconsistently, which might cause
    9000             :      * do_pg_abort_backup() to fail.
    9001             :      */
    9002         252 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9003             : 
    9004             :     /*
    9005             :      * It is expected that each do_pg_backup_start() call is matched by
    9006             :      * exactly one do_pg_backup_stop() call.

    9008         252 :     Assert(XLogCtl->Insert.runningBackups > 0);
    9009         252 :     XLogCtl->Insert.runningBackups--;
    9010             : 
    9011             :     /*

    9015             :      * cleaning up session-level lock because session-level lock doesn't need
    9016             :      * to be protected with WAL insertion lock. But since
    9017             :      * CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS() can occur in it, session-level lock must be
    9018             :      * cleaned up before it.

    9020         252 :     sessionBackupState = SESSION_BACKUP_NONE;
    9021             : 
    9022         252 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    9023             : 
    9024             :     /*
    9025             :      * If we are taking an online backup from the standby, we confirm that the
    9026             :      * standby has not been promoted during the backup.
    9027             :      */
    9028         252 :     if (state->started_in_recovery && !backup_stopped_in_recovery)
    9029           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    9030             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),
    9031             :                  errmsg("the standby was promoted during online backup"),
    9032             :                  errhint("This means that the backup being taken is corrupt "
    9033             :                          "and should not be used. "
    9034             :                          "Try taking another online backup.")));
    9035             : 
    9036             :     /*
    9037             :      * During recovery, we don't write an end-of-backup record. We assume that
    9038             :      * pg_control was backed up last and its minimum recovery point can be
    9039             :      * available as the backup end location. Since we don't have an
    9040             :      * end-of-backup record, we use the pg_control value to check whether
    9041             :      * we've reached the end of backup when starting recovery from this
    9042             :      * backup. We have no way of checking if pg_control wasn't backed up last
    9043             :      * however.
    9044             :      *
    9045             :      * We don't force a switch to new WAL file but it is still possible to
    9046             :      * wait for all the required files to be archived if waitforarchive is
    9047             :      * true. This is okay if we use the backup to start a standby and fetch
    9048             :      * the missing WAL using streaming replication. But in the case of an
    9049             :      * archive recovery, a user should set waitforarchive to true and wait for
    9050             :      * them to be archived to ensure that all the required files are
    9051             :      * available.
    9052             :      *
    9053             :      * We return the current minimum recovery point as the backup end
    9054             :      * location. Note that it can be greater than the exact backup end
    9055             :      * location if the minimum recovery point is updated after the backup of
    9056             :      * pg_control. This is harmless for current uses.
    9057             :      *
    9058             :      * XXX currently a backup history file is for informational and debug
    9059             :      * purposes only. It's not essential for an online backup. Furthermore,
    9060             :      * even if it's created, it will not be archived during recovery because
    9061             :      * an archiver is not invoked. So it doesn't seem worthwhile to write a
    9062             :      * backup history file during recovery.
    9063             :      */
    9064         252 :     if (backup_stopped_in_recovery)
    9065             :     {
    9066             :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    9067             : 
    9068             :         /*
    9069             :          * Check to see if all WAL replayed during online backup contain

    9071             :          */

    9076          10 :         if (state->startpoint <= recptr)
    9077           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
    9078             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_NOT_IN_PREREQUISITE_STATE),

    9109             : 
    9110             :         /*

    9112             :          * valid as soon as archiver moves out the current segment file.

    9115             :

    9127             :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
    9128             :                      errmsg("could not create file \"%s\": %m",
    9129             :                             histfilepath)));
    9130             : 
    9131             :         /* Build and save the contents of the backup history file */

    9133         242 :         fprintf(fp, "%s", history_file);
    9134         242 :         pfree(history_file);
    9135             : 
    9136         242 :         if (fflush(fp) || ferror(fp) || FreeFile(fp))
    9137           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
    9138             :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
    9139             :                      errmsg("could not write file \"%s\": %m",
    9140             :                             histfilepath)));
    9141             : 
    9142             :         /*
    9143             :          * Clean out any no-longer-needed history files.  As a side effect,
    9144             :          * this will post a .ready file for the newly created history file,
    9145             :          * notifying the archiver that history file may be archived
    9146             :          * immediately.
    9147             :          */
    9148         242 :         CleanupBackupHistory();
    9149             :     }
    9150             : 
    9151             :     /*
    9152             :      * If archiving is enabled, wait for all the required WAL files to be
    9153             :      * archived before returning. If archiving isn't enabled, the required WAL
    9154             :      * needs to be transported via streaming replication (hopefully with
    9155             :      * wal_keep_size set high enough), or some more exotic mechanism like
    9156             :      * polling and copying files from pg_wal with script. We have no knowledge
    9157             :      * of those mechanisms, so it's up to the user to ensure that he gets all
    9158             :      * the required WAL.
    9159             :      *
    9160             :      * We wait until both the last WAL file filled during backup and the
    9161             :      * history file have been archived, and assume that the alphabetic sorting
    9162             :      * property of the WAL files ensures any earlier WAL files are safely
    9163             :      * archived as well.
    9164             :      *
    9165             :      * We wait forever, since archive_command is supposed to work and we
    9166             :      * assume the admin wanted his backup to work completely. If you don't
    9167             :      * wish to wait, then either waitforarchive should be passed in as false,
    9168             :      * or you can set statement_timeout.  Also, some notices are issued to
    9169             :      * clue in anyone who might be doing this interactively.
    9170             :      */
    9171             : 
    9172         252 :     if (waitforarchive &&
    9173          18 :         ((!backup_stopped_in_recovery && XLogArchivingActive()) ||
    9174           2 :          (backup_stopped_in_recovery && XLogArchivingAlways())))

    9224             : 
    9225             : 
    9226             : /*
    9227             :  * do_pg_abort_backup: abort a running backup
    9228             :  *
    9229             :  * This does just the most basic steps of do_pg_backup_stop(), by taking the
    9230             :  * system out of backup mode, thus making it a lot more safe to call from
    9231             :  * an error handler.
    9232             :  *
    9233             :  * 'arg' indicates that it's being called during backup setup; so
    9234             :  * sessionBackupState has not been modified yet, but runningBackups has
    9235             :  * already been incremented.  When it's false, then it's invoked as a
    9236             :  * before_shmem_exit handler, and therefore we must not change state
    9237             :  * unless sessionBackupState indicates that a backup is actually running.
    9238             :  *
    9239             :  * NB: This gets used as a PG_ENSURE_ERROR_CLEANUP callback and
    9240             :  * before_shmem_exit handler, hence the odd-looking signature.
    9241             :  */
    9242             : void
    9243          18 : do_pg_abort_backup(int code, Datum arg)
    9244             : {
    9245          18 :     bool        during_backup_start = DatumGetBool(arg);
    9246             : 
    9247             :     /* If called during backup start, there shouldn't be one already running */
    9248          18 :     Assert(!during_backup_start || sessionBackupState == SESSION_BACKUP_NONE);
    9249             : 
    9250          18 :     if (during_backup_start || sessionBackupState != SESSION_BACKUP_NONE)
    9251             :     {
    9252          14 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9253          14 :         Assert(XLogCtl->Insert.runningBackups > 0);
    9254          14 :         XLogCtl->Insert.runningBackups--;
    9255             : 
    9256          14 :         sessionBackupState = SESSION_BACKUP_NONE;
    9257          14 :         WALInsertLockRelease();
    9258             : 
    9259          14 :         if (!during_backup_start)
    9260          14 :             ereport(WARNING,
    9261             :                     errmsg("aborting backup due to backend exiting before pg_backup_stop was called"));
    9262             :     }
    9263          18 : }
    9264             : 
    9265             : /*
    9266             :  * Register a handler that will warn about unterminated backups at end of
    9267             :  * session, unless this has already been done.
    9268             :  */
    9269             : void
    9270           8 : register_persistent_abort_backup_handler(void)
    9271             : {
    9272             :     static bool already_done = false;
    9273             : 
    9274           8 :     if (already_done)
    9275           2 :         return;
    9276           6 :     before_shmem_exit(do_pg_abort_backup, DatumGetBool(false));
    9277           6 :     already_done = true;
    9278             : }
